Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of two tenders submitted by both John F. Hannon and George Bertrand, for some changes in the electric lighting system at the Lorette Indian Boarding School.

Before these tenders can be given any consideration, I would ask you to please interview Mr. Bertrand and ask him to furnish me with a new tender stating exactly the number of new lights and switches which it is his intention to install in the cellar, second and third floors of the school.

Yours very truly,

(J. D. McLean)
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Indian Lorette,

Ottawa, May 12, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, relative to a grant to purchase prizes for the pupils of the Lorette Indian Day School to be awarded to them before the school closes for the coming Summer holidays.

In this connection I have to say that our funds for the present fiscal year are extremely limited, and I regret that it will not be possible to authorize any expenditure in the purchase of prizes for the pupils of Indian schools this year.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

P. A. Picard, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Jeune Lorette, P.Q.
EXTRACT from Report of Mr. Inspector A. A. Letarte, dated March 26th, 1930, on his inspection of the LORRETTE Indian Day School.

Original on File 14-1-6.

Schoolhouse has to be painted. The roof is still in bad condition, the water goes through at two places.

The gallery was repaired a little last year but it is not finished.

Pupils' desks have to be repaired or to be renewed.

There are two inside doors that we cannot open easily. These doors have to be fixed.

The suggestions that I have to make are to insist on the above improvements, which are urgent.
Ottawa, May 15, 1930.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of the Lorette Indian Day School in March, last, states that the roof of the building requires repairs, as the water leaks through in two places. He also states that repairs to the gallery were not finished last fall, and that this work should be done. He further states that repairs are required to the pupils' desks, and that two inside doors that cannot be opened easily should be repaired.

In connection with the above, I have to request that you will report on what repairs are required to the roof and gallery, also the cost of having the work done. You may arrange to have any repairs required made to the pupils' desks, and you should see that the two inside doors are placed in a satisfactory condition. Please furnish the information asked for at an early date, and arrange to have the desks and doors repaired.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

P. A. Picard, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Jeune Lorette,
P. Q.
Indian Lorette 19th May 1930

The Secretary
Dep't of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 15th inst., re day school, I beg to report that after careful examination, the repairs to the gallery and the roof leakage are estimated at about $25.00. These affect a part of the roof of the back verandah, and that under the balcony, where the boards are to be renewed and covered with new shingles.

As for the leakage which eventually was caused by the ice forming there during the last winters, and also by capillary attraction, a new piece of galvanized sheet iron will probably have to be placed in that angle of the main roof, with wider sides under the shingles. At the same time a search for the passage or loss of heat from the interior which it is thought strikes about that spot, will be made in order to stop this escape.

Furthermore, I will recommend that the whole roof be tarred, as its present condition is certainly in a very bad state; cost about $25.00.

The balcony roof needs a new covering which could be of galvanized sheet iron over the old shingles, and at about the cost of a new shingle covering; cost about $10.00. The two brick chimneys also need a few minor repairs.

In fact, I will recommend that the whole building be painted at the exterior, as by its appearance, several years have elapsed since the last painting. No estimate has been made for the letterwork.

Your obedient servant

Indian Agent
Ottawa, May 23rd, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, giving an estimate of the cost of the repairs required to the gallery and roof at the Lorette Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of your incurring the expenditure required in carrying out the repairs as mentioned in your letter to the gallery and roof. After these repairs have been completed, you may also arrange to have the whole roof tarred and any minor repairs required made to the two chimneys. It is noted you estimate the entire cost of the repairs, including the tarring of the roof, to be approximately $70.00. It is expected you will see that no unnecessary expense is incurred in having the work mentioned by you carried out. When the work has been completed to your satisfaction, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of any material supplied and for the labour in having the work done. These repairs should receive your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

A. S. Williams,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

P. A. Dionne, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Jeune Lorette, P.Q.

The Secretary
Dep't of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

Sir,

I beg to report that the reverend Sisters having left the school reserve for their holidays, have sent in a demand for an extra amount of $25.00 for extra work done in the classrooms before their departure. In fact, I have examined all the school rooms, and found that the floors have been cleaned, oiled and polished, the walls and ceiling scrubbed etc...and that a thorough painstaking cleaning has been made. I therefore recommend that the above amount be allowed them for this work.

Your obedient servant

Indian Agent
Ottawa, July 18, 1930.

Sir,

A request was made by the Reverend Sisters of the reserve dayschool, for a new kitchen stove for their own use.

In this connection, having had the actual stove examined by a plumber and having investigated myself, I am quite satisfied to say that this stove is unrepairable, being in a very bad state after quite a number of years in use. I therefore asked the Reverend Sisters to choose a new one which would serve for their best purposes and I beg to ask of the Department authorisation to purchase same, "Le Petit Rural" at $75.50 complete. Five dollars will be allowed for the old one, this amount to be deducted from the above price.

Your obedient servant

Ottawa, October 13, 1931.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of a voucher which you submit to the amount of $25.50 covering the cost of repairing seats at the Lorette Indian Day School. No authority appears to have been granted for the incurring of this expenditure. It is noted that vouchers which have been received from you lately covering the cost of work done or for supplies furnished do not show that any authority was granted for the expenditure shown on the face of the voucher.

In future, I have to request that, before incurring any expenditure which it is intended that the Department will be called upon to pay, authority be first obtained, otherwise the account cannot be paid. Our funds this year are extremely limited, and we can only authorize the most urgent work or absolutely necessary supplies. The account which you submit covering the cost of repairs to the desks will be paid, but, in future, it is expected that you will comply with the Department's requirements before undertaking any work or purchasing supplies.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, regarding the request which you received from the Sister Superior of the Lorette Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of an expenditure not exceeding the sum of $15 in the purchase of the garden seeds, and you may arrange, after consulting the Reverend Sister as to the seeds required, for the purchase from a firm on the list to receive consideration. The Department will also approve of a grant not exceeding the sum of $10 in the purchase of prizes for the pupils, to be distributed before the school closes for the coming summer holidays. You should obtain itemized accounts, in duplicate, covering the cost of the seeds and for the prizes. These accounts you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and send to the Department for payment.

Regarding the repairs required to the fence at the back of the school and also the replacing of broken glass in the windows, I have to say that the Department will approve of you arranging to have these repairs carried out. We will also approve of you arranging for the painting of the upstairs rooms in the school. You should arrange for the purchase of the paint, and any extra labour required should, if possible, be performed by the Indians. An account, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded by you, after the work has been completed, covering the cost of the repairs to the fence, installing of the glass and painting of the rooms with one coat of paint. The condition of the cellar in the Country Day School was brought to my attention. Dear Sir:

I have had the pleasure recently to meet your Mr. Mackenzie, and advised him that the roof of the Lorette Convent, is in a terrible state.

Water is going through the shingle roof, and will certainly spoil the inside.

I would suggest that a tin roof be put on before the cold weather sets in, and as the latter is very cheap at present, the expense would not be tremendous.

Kindly advise your wishes, and oblige.

Sincerely,

Indian Agent.

Ottawa, September 26, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, regarding the condition of the roof of the Lorette Indian Day School building.

In reply I have to request that you will state if it would not be possible, by making minor repairs, to place the roof in serviceable condition for the coming winter months. Our funds are so limited that it will not be possible to authorize having metallic roofing placed on the building this fall. Please state the type of roofing at present on the building. If it is shingled, would not a few repairs to prevent leakage during the present fall and winter months be sufficient? Please state the cost of carrying out the repairs that are absolutely urgent at the present time. You might also furnish an estimate of the cost of putting on metallic roofing, in order that we will have complete information when consideration is being given to placing an amount in our Estimates for next year to cover the cost.

An early reply giving the information asked for above is requested.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

A new roof, made with number one tin, would cost two hundred and twenty five dollars, or about. So you can base your estimates on the latter for next year, and advise at once as to the former.

Ottawa, April 7th, 1933.

Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 3rd instant, I beg to say that, except in cases of extreme urgency where delay may cause distress, no expenditures should be incurred without first obtaining authority from the Department at Ottawa. Should it be necessary to incur expenditure before departmental authority has been obtained, you should report same immediately to the Department for approval. It is considered, however, that, in the case of the Lorette Indian Day School, it is unlikely that anything will occur of so serious a nature as to necessitate your taking action without securing authority. I may add that telegrams should only be used in cases of extreme urgency.

The Department's funds during the current fiscal year are limited and Indian Agents and teachers are expected to cooperate with departmental officials in keeping expenditure to the lowest possible point.

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum: Mr. Sutherland,

While at Lorette last week my attention was brought to the condition of the cedar shingle roof of the day school convent, which is leaking in many places.

Ottawa, June 26, 1934.

Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 20th instant I beg to say that an officer of the Department expects to visit your Agency in the near future, and he will inspect the water system. When he reports, the Department will decide what repairs should be made.

Regarding the cockroaches in the convent, I may say that Bulletin No. 112 of the Department of Agriculture suggests the following:

"Cockroaches may be readily controlled by means of sodium fluoride. This material should be lightly dusted in places frequented by the roaches such as about sinks, baseboards, cupboards, hot water pipes, etc. The sodium fluoride adheres to the legs and antennae of the roaches, and in cleaning themselves the insects are poisoned by it. Sodium fluoride retains its effectiveness and may be left undisturbed as long as convenient or until the cockroaches have completely disappeared. As the chemical is somewhat poisonous reasonable precautions should be taken to prevent children or domestic pets from gaining access to it.

"Two other materials which form the basis of many proprietary roach powders and which often are recommended, are pyrethrum and borax. Pyrethrum insect powder is less effective than sodium fluoride, it loses its effectiveness quickly on exposure to air and has to be used in larger quantities. Borax, also, is less satisfactory than sodium fluoride. It is easily obtainable, however, and mixed with equal parts of powdered sweet chocolate, is a fairly effective remedy. Superheating and fumigation with hydrocyanic acid gas are also effective in destroying cockroaches. In the case of hydrocyanic acid gas fumigation, however, our experiments indicate that a concentration of gas produced by using 1/2 lbs. of calcium cyanide per 1,000 cubic feet, although effective against nymphs and adults, does not destroy the eggs."

You will note from the above that fumigation by gas is not recommended, and, therefore, the Department is not prepared to authorize the expenditure that would be required for this purpose. You may, however, purchase the sodium fluoride which is required. This can be secured at any drugstore, at a low cost.

Your obedient servant,

Mr. Maurice Bastien, Jr.,
Indian Agent

Sir:

I have your letter of the 10th instant, enclosing a communication from the Sister Superior of the Lorette Convent, requesting certain repairs and materials.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange to have knobs installed on the doors of the water closets; hooks fixed on windows, window glass replaced where required and school benches repaired. In having these repairs carried out, you should keep the costs as low as possible. You may arrange for the purchase and delivery of 3 brooms, one dozen bars of soap for cleaning purposes, one brush, 25 lbs. dustbins and one cocoa door mat. Please obtain accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost of the repairs and the materials, which you should certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

The Sister Superior states that the water does not reach the upper floors - possibly on account of defective piping or perhaps because the pipe is too small. Please submit an estimate of the cost of having the piping renewed or placed in a satisfactory condition, so that an ample supply of water will reach the second floor.

The Sister further draws attention to the condition of the drain from the cellar. Please state if there is any outlet from the cellar to drain off the water. If there is an old drain for this purpose, no doubt it is blocked. If a new drain is required, you should state the length necessary. Please give full particulars regarding this matter and submit an estimate of the cost of either repairing the present drain or installing a new one that would be satisfactory to carry off the water from the cellar.

Our funds this year are extremely limited, and, unless the renewing of the piping for water supply and the installing of a drain are absolutely necessary, favourable consideration could not be given to authorizing the expenditure required in having the work carried out.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Wish to advise of the following matters in reference to local Convent. The fence is in a miserable state, most of it is broken down and would cost some $200.00 for a new one, I propose getting a group of Indians under relief and make them put it up again as well as possible, when it, this to be done without remuneration, the only part that bothers me is they may have to get a few new boards to replace broken ones at a total cost of some $10.00. The sidewalk leading from the Main Road to the Convent is in the same state and intend to proceed likewise, with your approval.

Could you spend some $50.00 to $60.00 to repaint part of outside, Indians would also do this without being paid, most of the paint is gone and the need is urgent to save the wood.

I ask you the usual grant of ten dollars for prizes to be given out to students at the end of the school term, this is appreciated so much. I also need a good size rope to tie the flag to the mast here.

Will you give this your immediate attention, and oblige.

Yours Respectfully,

Indian Agent.

Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, May 13th, 1935.

Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 9th instant, I beg to say that you may arrange for the purchase of the lumber required to repair the fence and the sidewalk at the Lorette Indian Day School. You may, also, expend an amount not exceeding $60.00 in the purchase of paint. In this case, also, it is noted that the labour will be done by Indians free of cost.

The Department is not prepared to authorize any expenditure this year for the purchase of prizes to be given to the pupils at the end of the school term.

Ottawa, June 27, 1935.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 17th instant, regarding the voucher which you submitted in favour of Bastien Brothers, to reimburse them for payments made by them covering the cost of electric light service to the Lorette Indian Convent for the period from December 2, 1932, to May 15, 1935.

It is necessary to return the voucher, with the receipted accounts attached. It is noted that some of the accounts show a minimum charge of $1.00, while on others the minimum charge is $1.25. We are not aware why there should be this variation in these charges. I would request that you obtain a copy of the contract from the Quebec Power Company setting forth their rates, and forward same to the Department.

It is noted that several of the accounts show arrears. I may say that the Treasury Department will not pay arrears on electric light accounts. A number of the accounts do not show that the discount allowed was obtained. In any reimbursement, it will be necessary to deduct the discount.

It appears that accounts for the following months are missing: May, July, August and October, 1933; May, July and December, 1934, and January 1935. The account for August, 1934, shows an overpayment of $1.50, and the account for October, 1934, shows a credit of 50 cents. An explanation should be given regarding these two accounts. If you paid these missing accounts, you should obtain copies, certify that they have been paid, and prepare a new voucher, in triplicate, for the amount due, which you should also certify and forward to the Department. You should also furnish an explanation regarding the other accounts referred to.

You will see the difficulty there is in making payment of these delayed accounts, as it is not always possible, at this late date, to make any correction of errors. However, you should furnish full explanations as requested, and return the accounts, with a voucher attached, when consideration will be given to payment.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Indian Agent,

We firmly hope that we shall not be disappointed in this matter which we undertook upon your request.

It is very important that you should reply to us as soon as possible concerning the enlargement of the convent; otherwise, the classrooms shall continue to be over-filled and the progress and amelioration of the education of the Huron school children shall remain inexistent. And yet, you seemed sincere enough when you wrote to us concerning your very laudable decision.

I trust you will forward a favourable reply as soon as possible.

Yours faithfully,

(Signed) Sr. St. Vincent-Ferrier,
Superior.
Dear Madam,-

With reference to your letter of the 7th instant, it is regretted that the books you ordered have not yet reached you. However, you can be assured that the order will be placed and the books will be available for the next academic year.

With regard to the last paragraph of your letter, it is not found possible to provide funds this year for enlarging the Lorette Indian Day School. You will realize that it is extremely difficult to obtain funds that are required for the many pressing demands that we receive.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes.
Secretary.

I made an inspection of the Lorette reserve on January 28th and beg to submit the following report.

Agency Buildings

The school house is the only one owned by the Department. This is an old building and some repairs are needed; roof-hip type—has been renewed in part only about five years ago, the balance then considered good enough, is now badly leaking in many places and should now be renewed as the water has damaged ceiling and walls in upper part of building. Verandah roof is also leaking all over, and floor of small verandah at back of building will have to be renewed or the most of it. The outside of the building needs a coat of paint which could be put on by some of the Indians now on relief.

I noticed that there was no fire escape; an ordinary iron ladder could be set up at end of building to reach the roof, in case of fire, and passing near the dormitory window, would be used as fire escape if needed. The cost would not be very high.

The fence around the grounds is in a dilapidated state and gives the premises an air of abandonment which is not pleasant to the eye.

I noticed that fifteen double desks in the classrooms are not fit to be used and should be replaced. The inside of the whole building is kept exceptionally clean.

The old electric washing machine is obsolete and should really be replaced.

Statement of expenditure—estimated.

Part of roof on house and on verandahs............. $150.00
Small verandah floor and inside minor repairs...... 25.00
Fence around the school grounds.................... 150.00
Iron ladder—installed—to roof..................... 40.00
New electric washing machine....................... 75.00
Fifteen new double desks.......................... ?

School boys and girls all appeared to be healthy and bright.

J. Thibault,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Quebec Inspectorate.

Dear Sir:

Dear Sir:

Up to now, the books asked for the school term 1938-1939, haven't arrived yet, will you give this your attention at once, and oblige.

There are five teachers at the Convent this year, and a small chiffonnier for one of the rooms, is needed. Either a second hand or new one will do.

I also wrote you last year about getting an electric washing machine for the teachers, and heard no more about same, will you kindly give this your attention.

Thanks.

Yours Respectfully,

Indian Agent.

Ottawa, Ont.
Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 19th instant the Department has no record of having received a requisition for school supplies for the Lorette Indian Day School. The last requisition received from this school was in October, 1937.

Please let me know the approximate cost of the chiffonnier which you recommend be supplied.

The Purchasing Agent has been requested to secure the electric washing machine and it is hoped that this will be shipped in the near future.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Lorette Convent - Lighting Service.

I have your letter of January 26th., claiming that our cheque for $9.14 was not sufficient to balance your account. Extract from Inspector's report on Lorette Indian day school visited on February 13, 1939.

The ventilation of the W.C. is no good. Complaints were made that there is a disagreeable smell when the W.C. are used. It must depend on the cess-pool.

I was in school when the fireman was warming and it was insupportable to smell the gaz. The fireman must not know how to heat a furnace.

Dear Sir:

In reporting on his inspection of the Lorette Indian day school on the 13th instant Inspector Letarte states that the ventilation in the closets should be improved. No doubt this will only involve a small expenditure and you may arrange for the necessary work.

The Inspector states that the smell of gas in the school was very pronounced on the day of his visit. Apparently the man in charge of the furnace was not performing his duties properly on that day at least. Please give the man in charge of the furnace instructions regarding its proper operation.

M. F. R. L. Macdonald Secrétaire

Monsieur le Secrétaire,

Nous sommes de retour au couvent du Village Huron et je dois vous dire combien nous avons été étonnés à la vue du couvent non réparé. En vérité cette maison n'est presque plus habitable : l'eau pénètre par le toit, les galeries ne tiennent presque pas, les conduits pour l'eau ne donnent pas assez de rendement, la rouille empêche la pression des boîtes se remplissent très lentement, ce qui occasionne de grands maux par l'odeur désagréable qui se répand dans les classes. Le mobilier des classes est sans...
bon sens, les élèves se plaignent de ce qu'ils fatiguent sur leurs lances.
Nous espérons que vous porterez attention au moins pour l'eau et le mobilier ce qui équivaudrait une somme de $300 à $375.

Signatures: Le 15 de M. P. de SS.
Par le St Jean de Malba Supérieure
Huron Village, August 23, 1939.

T. R. L. MacInnes, Esq.,
Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Dear Sir:

We have just returned to the Convent of the Huron Village and we cannot tell you how disappointed we are over the convent not having been repaired. Indeed, this house is almost uninhabitable; the roof leaks, the verandas are falling apart, the water pipes are too small, rust cuts down the water pressure and the boxes fill very slowly, giving off a very bad odor in the classrooms.

The classroom furniture is in bad shape and the pupils complain that the seats are very uncomfortable.

We trust that you will at least look after the water supply and the furniture, which would require an expenditure from $300.00 to $375.00

Yours truly,

(sgd.) Sister St.Jean de Matha,
Superior.
Village des Hurons, Que.
August 21st, 1939

Dear Sir:

Many times I have brought to your attention, the general condition of the school house.

The school desks need repair, the roof is leaking quite badly, the upper part of the Convent need general repairs, and soon will amount to a lot of money. I would estimate an amount of about two hundred dollars and this should be done at once. Everytime an inspector has come, he has been shown these, and has taken note almost without result. The Nuns have been complaining bitterly and I can give them very little satisfaction, consequently would ask you to see about this at the earliest possible date, as schools will soon open and the teachers are back. Thanks.

Respectfully,

[Signature]

Mr. Secretary,

On our order for the month of May, we requested 500 ruled ink copybooks with historical covers, sold by the Canadian General Library, 5608 Starling Ave., Montreal. As we did not receive them, we wrote again adding to our order 18 "Manuels d'Hygiène de Bienséances et Civisme", written by a number of professors, for classes 5, 6, 7 and 8 of the Elementary grades; 6 illustrated composition books for the 6th and 7th grades; one master's copy of the same; procurable from the Frères de l'Instruction Chrétienne, Laprairie, Montréal. We have not received any of the above.

This fact is detrimental to our students; we shall expect an answer in the next eight days; else, we shall order the material and send you the bill.

10 simple desks with chairs for students between 12 and 14 years of age

Cong des SS. de M. D. du P. S. Mission de Lorette
1er nov. 1939

M. T. R. L. MacInnes Secrétaire,

Monsieur,

M. Louis Thibault d'Armagh,
Comté de Bellechasse P.Q., chez qui nous avons envoyé l'ordre pour les pupitres et chaises, nous avions qu'il accepte la commande aux conditions mentionnées; mais que vous auriez à payer le transport.
Ces bois et chaises seront prêts dans une quinzaine de jours. Si les chemins sont encore passables dans cette région à cette date, nous ferons le transport en chercher pour Noël ou Noël, sinon ce sera pas les chais qu'ils nous seront expédiés.

Veuillez avoir l'obligeance de me dire ce que nous aurons à faire.
dans ce cas.

J'espère de l'occasion pour vous dire que la séparation faite sur le toit ne veut à rien. Nous continuons de péneter. Les ouvriers disent que le bois est pourri en dessous de la toile et que les clous ne peuvent plus tenir. Nous remarquons la même chose pour les boiseries des châssis et les pièces de bois qui reposent sur le solage. L'extérieur de la maison est dans un piteux état ainsi que le trottoir et la clôture qui entoure le terrain de l'école.

J'espère que vous tiendrez compte de ces choses et que d'ici au printemps prochain nous enverrons quelqu'un d'expert qui sera en mesure de juger ce qu'il y aura à faire afin que les séparations se fassent à temps et durant la belle saison.

Grégoire obligeé le 17. M. D. O. D.

Par le Sr Jean de Matha
Couvent de Lorette Village Hudson.
Cong. des SS. de N.D. du P.S., Lorette, Nov. 1, 1939.

T.R.L. MacInnes, Esq., Secretary,

Sir,

Mr. Louis Thibault, of Armagh, Bellechasse Co., P.Q., to whom we sent the order for desks and chairs, has notified us that he accepted the order under the terms mentioned, but that you would have to pay the transportation charges. These desks and chairs will be ready in about two weeks. If the roads are still open to traffic in that district at that time, we could send for them at a cost of about $10. to $15; if not, they will have to be shipped by train. Kindly tell us what we are to do in such a case.

I take this opportunity to inform you that the repairs to the roof were of no avail, as it is still leaking. The workmen claim that the wood is decayed under the tin and that the nails cannot hold. The same condition is noticed in regard to the window frames and the timber resting upon the foundations. The outside of the house is in a poor condition as well as the sidewalks and the fence enclosing the school grounds.

I trust that you will take the above into consideration and that you will send before spring an expert who will be in a position to determine what is needed, and that the repairs will be done during the spring and summer.

Yours truly,

The SS. de N.D. du P.S.,
by Rev. Sister St. Jean
de Matha,
Huron Village of Lorette.
Ottawa,
November 10, 1939.

Dear Madam:

With reference to your letter of the 1st instant I may say that when your previous letter was received it was understood that the price quoted covered delivery to Loretteville.

It is now noted that it will involve an expenditure of ten or fifteen dollars for transportation of the desks from Armagh to Loretteville. If necessary you may incur an expenditure of this amount.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. Sister St. Jean de Matha,
Lorette Indian Day School,
Loretteville, Que.
You will notice that the accounts sent by Mr. Garneau were substantially increased without your authority. We relied in this connection on what Mr. Origène Sicou told us to the effect that we could make repairs for an amount of nearly $200. I thought that these items could be included. Please excuse us if we have acted thus, but we have requested only the articles which were absolutely necessary.

Monsieur le Secrétaire,

Vous trouverez que les factures envoyées par M. Garneau ont été augmentées de beaucoup sans votre autorisation. Je me suis basée sur ce que M. Origène Sicou m'a dit que nous pouvions faire des réparations pour près de $200. J'ai pensé que ces articles pouvaient être compris là-dedans.

Veuillez m'excuser si j'ai eu tort d'agir ainsi. Nous avons demandé que ce qui était d'extrême nécessité

Votre toute dévouée,

S. St Jean de Malba Supérieure.

Dear Sir,

Since you have decided not to allow tuition grants for more than ten Indian boys at the Commercial Academy of Loretteville, and that the teachers of the local convent will be left over with some of the older boys for further teaching, the Superior has brought a list of tools she would ask the Department to supply, as they would try and show the elementary work of carpentry to these older boys.

They would also try and get repaired the fence around the convent, for which a grant was asked, the only thing to supply would be the wood for an amount of about twenty-five to thirty dollars.

I imagine that the total cost of these tools would be twenty dollars. May I have your permission to arrange for this?

Thanks,

Yours Respectfully,

M.E. Bastien,
Indian Agent.

Village des Hurons, Qué.,
April 19th, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I had the visit this morning, of
the Superior of the Lorette Convent, who made the following
demands: The usual grand of $12.00 for seeds, to sow the
piece of land adjoining the Convent. She needs 100 lbs. of
lime to paint the old fence surrounding the Convent. Three
gallons of green paint, half gallon of white, three gallons
of white, three gallons of grey, to paint the new frontal
fence erected by the students, since last fall.

If you could supply, ten gallons of
cheap grey paint, two gallons of white, and ten pounds of
putty, could get the outside of Convent painted free by
those on relief.

The roof is also in bad shape,
they must use pails in many places inside to collect the
water; would cost about $50.00 to put roof paint. They
need aluminum paint to fix radiators. Also one heavy pole
to hang their wet clothing.

Trust you can afford to grant the
above, and oblige.

Respectfully,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 19th instant the following expenditures are approved:

1. An amount of $12.00 for the purchase of seeds;
2. 100 Lbs. lime to paint the fence;
3. An amount of $50.00 for repairing the roof.

The paint for the exterior painting of the school is being secured by the Purchasing Branch. It is noted that you will be able to have the work done free of cost by those receiving relief.

Our funds are limited and the above expenditures for repairs and improvements at the Lorette School are all that can be considered for the current fiscal year.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. M.E. Bastien,
Indian Agent,
Loretteville, Que.
Memorandum:

Mr. Hoey,

With reference to your requisition of the 25th ultimo, for painting supplies for repairing the Lorette Indian Day School, I may say that we have secured a quotation from Alfred Verret, Loretteville, P.Q., of $34.80. Mr. Verret quotes on Ramsay paints; $2.25 per gallon for the grey; $2.35 for the white, and .06¢ per pound for the putty. If the quality of paint offered at these quoted prices is satisfactory to Indian Agent Bastien it will be in order for him to buy the supplies from this source. We suspect, however, that either a second or third quality of paint is being quoted on, or that there has been an error in the prices quoted, as they are below the current prices for standard paints. If the grade offered is not satisfactory, it will be in order for Mr. Bastien to procure a higher grade of good standard paint.

H.J. Davidson

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 19th ultimo requesting paint for the Lorette Indian Day School the Purchasing Branch has obtained the following quotation from Mr. Alfred Verret, Loretteville Quebec: Grey paint, $2.25 per gallon; white paint, $2.35 per gallon; putty, 6¢ per pound; total cost of the quantity required, $34.80.

The Purchasing Branch believes that the paint on which Mr. Verret has quoted is second or third quality. If the quality of the paint offered at the above prices is satisfactory you may buy the paint from Mr. Verret.

If the grade offered is not satisfactory you may procure a higher grade of good standard paint. As a general rule it is considered inadvisable to use cheap paint.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,

Dear Sir:

I am returning the attached paylist covering the cost of labour at the Lorette Indian Day School.

Dear Sir:

Enclosing for your attention a letter written by the Superior of the Convent here.

There is only one spot I wish to call your attention to, where the school boys using a long ladder belonging to a neighbor Michel Sioui, let it fall down and broke it in two.

The teacher wishes to know if the Department could replace same, as this poor Indian cannot buy another one for his home.

Your attention will oblige.

Respectfully,

M.E. Bastien
Indian Agent.

Mr. Phelan
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.,
Monsieur M. Bastien,

Monsieur l'Agent,

Dimanche le 7 juin, M. Maurice Vincent, Sous-Chef, m'a remis #10.00 pour acheter des prix aux élèves en me disant que vous me permettriez la dépense de la même somme en votre nom. La joie des enfants a été bien grande en recevant ces prix dont ils avaient fait le sacrifice et tous sont satisfaits et reconnaissants.

Les maîtres se joignent à moi pour vous remercier des précieux encouragements que vous avez bien voulu donner à la cause de l'éducation et de l'instruction.

Ci-inclus la facture des prix donnés en votre nom avec un surplus de deux dollars de Merci et les membres du
Conseil : une partie de la balance a servi à payer une balance chez Langlais et l'autre a été distribuée en monnaie.

Pour peindre la maison les peintres se sont servis d'une échelle appartenant à M. Sionni le voisin, la veille de la procession les enfants aidés de ma sœur St Aubin ont voulu la descendre et ils l'ont échappée, nous comprenons bien qu'elle s'est cassée. J'ai offert à ce Monsieur de la rembourser avec l'argent de la communauté mais quoique cette échelle lui soit indispensable en cas d'incendie il n'a pas voulu accepter cette offre. Cet accident ayant été causé par les enfants ne pourriez-vous pas la lui remettre en la faisant payer par le gouvernement ? Si oui je vous en serais bien reconnaissant !... c'est toujours regrettable de causer des dommages sans pouvoir remettre surtout quand il s'agit d'une famille dans la gêne.

À propos, le jeune Marcel fils de cette même famille souffre d'amygda-
lite au point de neire à ses classes.
S. St Aubin me dit que vous avez le pouvoir
d'obtenir cette opération gratuitement. Serait-
ce trop vous obliger ?

Avant de partir, je tiens
à vous remercier de tout ce que vous avez
fait pour nous en rendant notre maison
assez confortable.

Bien humble en N.S.
S. Marie de la Paix Suprême.
Ottawa, July 6, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, in which you state that a ladder belonging to Michael Sioui was broken by boys of the Lorette Indian Day School. Please let me know what it would cost to replace this ladder.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

ture, les moustiquaires pour porte

soin se fait sentir. Notre poêle de

née qui a besoin d'être bon

Vous serait-il possible d'employer quelqu'un pour faire ce travail et quelques autres séparations : vitres à poser, poignées de portes à séparer, pentes, etc. Nous avons fait les petites séparations dont nous étions capables, et si vous pouviez nous procurer 1 doz. de crochets pour fenêtres; 2 poignées de longueur, 2 crochets de 20 à 25 pes. 2 verrous pour portes de toilette; 2 pes. nous les ferons nous mêmes. Sir:

Please accept our thanks for the supplies which we received for our classes. The fencing and screens for windows and doors, are still lacking but we are informed that you are having them made. The note-books, pencils and rulers requested from the Government have not yet arrived.

There is another pressing need: our kitchen stove and the furnace in the cellar are not drawing well and are not giving good heat. They are very difficult to light up and smoke considerably. No doubt the chimney needs a good cleaning. Could you send someone to attend to this as well as to other minor repairs: window panes to be replaced door knobs to be repaired, hinges, etc. We have attended to some minor repairs ourselves, as far as we could, and if we could obtain one dozen 2-inch hooks for the windows and two 20-to-25-inch hooks together with two 2-inch bolts for w.c. doors. We will put them up ourselves.

I believe we will run short of fuel wood. I am informing you in advance so that you may purchase more before it becomes too scarce.

If it were possible for you to visit the convent, we would be pleased to make your acquaintance and specially show you the necessity for these things. I would also let you judge by yourself the fact that the floor of two rooms require a linoleum. The floor is of soft wood and the boards are split and almost worn through under the legs of the bed. Department of Mines & Resources,

Ottawa, Ont.,

Dear Sir;-

Last spring the writer asked your Department, for the supply of a good cooking stove for the Lorette Convent. You asked to enquire about a price and in sending the sketch of same, I was quoted $150.00 which you thought too expensive.

Considering the quality and number of years of service I still recommend same as it is now more than urgent, the Nuns have to go to an Indians' home near the Convent, to do part of their cooking.

Kindly advise.

Respectfully,

Maurice E. Bastien,
Indian Agent.

September 10th, 1947

Department of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.,

Dear Sirs:-

As ordered by your inspector Mr. Doucet, an all around utility man has repaired the local convent, and done a very fine job of it. All inside painted, desks repaired as well as ceilings in the teachers Residence. A new veranda built outside and nice fence around the property.

I have also ordered a new stove for the teachers, and there are two things remaining to be done to complete the job and be an asset to the Reserve and your Department; First putting new linoleum on the floors of two classes and painting the outside of the Convent.

I imagine that the two jobs represent an expenditure of some five hundred dollars, I hope it is possible to do so as this is an old building and it will prevent you of a much higher expenditure soon.

Trusting you will see your way to do so.

Respectfully,

Maurice E. Bastien
Indian Agent.

PS: Linoleum $200.00
Painting $300.00

Memorandum: Indian Affairs Branch.

Re: Purchase Order 25540

We note from Mr. Neary's memorandum of the 5th instant that the vendors are charging an additional amount of $25.19 for the stove covered by the above order.

There have been increases in this type of equipment between the time the order was placed, August 28th, and the date of the invoice, December 17th, 1947. Likewise, Mr. Bastien authorized delivery at the increased price, due to the urgent need of the stove.

Under the circumstances, and in view of the fact that we were not furnished with a tender, or quotation, in writing which would be binding in any way on the vendor, it will be in order to arrange for payment of the account of Quincaillerie Verret Engr., as rendered.

I would like to point out to you the following, about the local Convent:

Department of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.,

Dear Sir;-

I had an interview with the teachers of the Lorette Day School, who advise me that for the next school term of 1949-50, they will have from 70 to 72 Indian students following their classes. I also understand that you have estimates of eleven thousand dollars for the repair of the present convent, built about forty five years ago.

When Mr. Doucet was here last, he truthfully stated that it was useless to spend that money on such an old school. I am writing this letter to ask you to give the Reserve a new convent, with decent quarters for the teachers. They have so far been living in quarters which are far from decent, if we consider their position.

The question of having Loretteville build a school to receive the Indian students is surely out of order, if you consider that their convent is over one half of a mile from the Village and as we have mostly young children from five up, you can imagine what would happen in the winter months. Furthermore Loretteville will not build schools to accommodate other municipalities, they have enough to look after their own. They do not object to accept them when they are old enough to go to college, but again only when there is room left to take them. This year they refused a few we had ready for the eight grade, having no facilities to accept them.

I hope you will take these facts into consideration, and arrange for a new convent at once.

Respectfully,

Maurice E. Bastien,
Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

SUPERINTENDENT OF INDIAN EDUCATION

Re: Lorette Indian Day School

It is recommended that a two room school with teacher's residence be built on this reserve. Advanced pupils and boys of advanced age would be encouraged to attend provincial institutions whenever possible. This would leave an enrolment of approximately 70 pupils. This proposition was discussed with the teachers in the presence of the agent and the Regional Supervisor and seems to be satisfactory to all parties concerned. Mr. Ross, who was doing work for the sawmill at Lorette, corresponded and worked off the locality where the school should be situated. It will be a great satisfaction to these people to see a new school take the place of the old building which has been there for approximately 50 years. This building is beyond economical repair.

Respectfully submitted,

A. J. Doucet,
Supervisor, Vocational Education.

Ottawa, June 27, 1949.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Lorette Indian Day School.

Included in our main estimates for 1949-50 is the sum of $11,000.00 for the construction of a one-room additional classroom at the above school. We had intended to try to carry on with the old frame building for another two or three years, but have now received two reports on the building which indicate that it will have to be condemned. Therefore it is our recommendation that we erect a new two-room school at a cost of approximately $32,000.00 and transfer funds so that this project can be completed this year.

In addition to the reports from our own officials, the Provincial School Inspector stated as follows in his report of May 19, 1949:

"The school is very old. I recommend a new school for the benefit of teachers and pupils. Spending money on repairs is useless."

We have requested authority for the transfer of funds under separate cover and would request that authority be given for the calling of contracts in accordance with the advertisement attached hereto.

Enclosure.

Director.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources has provided for the construction of a two-room Indian Day School and attached teacher's residence on the Lorette Indian Reserve, Lorette Indian Agency, Province of Quebec, for the education of the Indian children living there;

THAT, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Act, tenders have been advertised for in local and trade newspapers;

THAT we have received, as a result of these advertisements, the following five tenders:

Joseph Eugene Tremblay,
127 de la Ronde St., Quebec City, P.Q. ........ $42,102.60

Keet Construction Company, Gros Pin, P.Q. .......... $43,750.50

Magloire Cauchon, Ltd., Quebec City, P.Q. .......... $44,870.00

Alfred Parent,
174 Rue Racine, Loretteville, P.Q. ............... $48,868.00

Eugene Jinchereau,
321 de la Salle, Quebec City, P.Q. .............. $52,500.00

THAT the above tenders have been examined by Departmental officials and it is found that they comply with the conditions outlined on tender forms which had been prepared by the Indian Affairs Branch and the plans and specifications as prepared by the Lands and Development Services Branch;

THAT Departmental officials recommend the acceptance of the lowest tender, namely that of Joseph Eugene Tremblay, 127 de la Ronde St., Quebec City, P.Q., in an amount of Forty-Two Thousand, One Hundred and Two Dollars and Sixty Cents ($42,102.60);

MEMORANDUM

Ottawa, October 14, 1949.

Re: Lorette Indian Day School,
Plan No. 891

In reply to your marginal notation dated October 11th on memorandum of October 7th from the Director of Indian Affairs in which he states that it has been brought to his attention that the flat roof provided on the above plan is too weak.

The information conveyed to the Director of Indian Affairs is definitely incorrect, the roof being quite safe for the loads to be supported. It has been designed in accordance with the allowable stresses specified by the National Building Code as well as that of the National Lumber Manufacturers Association, which codes also provide for a factor of safety.

In connection with Major MacKay's observation regarding 2" x 4" studs in the bearing partition, we may say that while these bearing partitions are capable of carrying the loads they are called upon to support, it is felt that we might improve the design by some changes to simplify this construction so that this question will not be brought up again in the field.

The 2" x 4" studs of bearing partition under the 2" x 12" joists @ 12" centres, have been changed therefore to 2" x 6" @ 12" centres and the 2" x 4" studs in basement partition under the living quarters to 2" x 6" @ 16" centres.

A blueprint showing the changes in stud bearing partitions as explained above, is being sent direct to the contractor today.

Chief, Engineering and Construction Division.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,

MEMORANDUM

Re: Lorette Indian Day School,
Plan No. 891

In reply to your marginal notation dated October 11th on memorandum of October 7th from the Director of Indian Affairs in which he states that it has been brought to his attention that the flat roof provided on the above plan is too weak.

The information conveyed to the Director of Indian Affairs is definitely incorrect, the roof being quite safe for the loads to be supported. It has been designed in accordance with the allowable stresses specified by the National Building Code as well as that of the National Lumber Manufacturers Association, which codes also provide for a factor of safety.

In connection with Major MacKay's observation regarding 2" x 4" studs in the bearing partition, we may say that while these bearing partitions are capable of carrying the loads they are called upon to support, it is felt that we might improve the design by some changes to simplify this construction so that this question will not be brought up again in the field.

The 2" x 4" studs of bearing partition under the 2" x 12" joists @ 12" centres have been changed therefore to 2" x 6" @ 12" centres and the 2" x 4" studs in basement partition under the living quarters to 2" x 6" @ 16" centres.

A blueprint showing the changes in stud bearing partitions as explained above, is being sent direct to the contractor today.

C. Victor T. Weir
Chief, Engineering and Construction Division.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,

Memorandum:

CHIEF, EDUCATION DIVISION

Lorette Indian Day School

The Lorette School contract was given for the sum of $42,102.60. There will be several extras on this contract for the following reasons:

(1) The estimate apparently was based on the plans which gave the levels. These plans did not take into consideration the depression of the land which would, according to the plans, put the buildings about three feet below road level which was very undesirable.

(2) Providing for a dispensary for the Medical Branch.

(3) Because of an error in the plans themselves.

No. 1 will require extra cement, extra refill, extra lumber for forms and scaffolding and also extra labour.

The coal bin is being used as a washroom for the Sisters and also for Domestic Science purposes and hence needed an exit to the outside from this room. The height of the foundation at the rear was suitable for a door in the foundation here which was agreed to. This part should not exceed the cost of the door and the slight labour required which would be approximately $40.

The extra plumbing required for a toilet and a wash basin will amount to approximately $350. This extra should be charged to the Medical Branch since it was authorized for
their convenience.

An answer from our memorandum suggesting an error in the plans of the school was agreeable. As a result new instructions were sent directly from the architect's office ordering the contractor to make the changes according to the new plans sent him. These plans required the change of 2" x 4"'s to 2" x 6"'s, also the doubling of the plates and a change in spacing which requires more material and more labour. The contractor was advised to send in these extras as soon as they were completed in order that we may prepare to meet these extra charges.

The outside of the school will require quite a bit of filling in. While in Lorette I interviewed a gentleman who has the equipment and who stated that this equipment was idle during the winter. Due to these facts he is prepared to give us a better price for this work during the slack season. He was asked to submit a tender to the Superintendent.

At a discussion with the Chiefs of the Reserve, Mr. Gendron and the Superintendent, it was suggested that the old school should be given to the Welfare department for the construction of three small residences for needy Indians. I believe Mr. Gendron, before he left, submitted a report on this matter. I would recommend that we dispose of the school in this manner on the understanding that it should be removed and the site levelled by those who take possession.

A.J. Doucet,
Supervisor of Vocational Education.

e) When the Consumer is caught in the act of tampering with the Supplier's apparatus or when there is prima facie evidence of tampering with the Supplier's apparatus.

f) When the Consumer fails to pay the amount of the Supplier's duly rendered bill within the time prescribed in the rules and regulations. DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Lorette Indian Day School,
Lorette Indian Agency, Province
of Quebec, Electoral District of
Quebec-Montmorency.

P.C. 4355 dated August 31st, 1949, awarded
contract to Joseph Eugene Tremblay, 127 de la Ronde
Street, Quebec City, P.Q., for the erection of a two-
room day school with teacher's living quarters attached.

After construction commenced, it was found
necessary to make certain changes, and as a consequence,
extras in an amount of $6,802.72 were incurred. The
following is an explanation of the extras.

1. The original estimate submitted by the company was
evidently based on our plans which gave the levels.
These plans did not take into consideration the
depression of the land, and if the plans had been
followed, the building would have been placed about
three feet below road level, which was undesirable.
To overcome this difficulty, we required extra cement,
extra refill, extra lumber for forms and also extra
labour.

2. In addition, it was found that the room originally
shown on the plans as a coal bin would be required
for a washroom for the Sisters in charge of the
school, and also for Domestic Science purposes.
Consequently, this required an exit to the outside.
Extra plumbing for the toilet and wash basin was
also required.
3. After construction commenced, it was found that there was a mistake in the plans, and as a result, new instructions were sent directly from the architect's office ordering the contractor to make certain changes. This involved changing the 2" x 4"'s to 2" x 6"'s, also the doubling of the plates and a change in spacing, which required considerably more material and labour.

The building has recently been completed, and an Engineer from the Department of Resources and Development reported on it in a memorandum dated April 12th, 1950, as follows:

"Structurally, both materials and workmanship are good. The sub-trades, plumbing, heating and electrical contracts, were carried out by competent firms and the installation of these facilities are very satisfactory. Certain local conditions that developed after the contract was awarded, necessitated changes being made in the original plans, and as a result, extras had to be allowed in order to meet the requirements. These extras have been carried out in a satisfactory manner, and the amount requested by the contractor for them is considered reasonable."

Memorandum to Council is enclosed.

PP/ST

Director.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Lorette Indian Day School,
Lorette Indian Agency, Province of Quebec, Electoral District of Quebec-Montmorency.

P.C. 4355 dated August 31st, 1949, awarded contract to Joseph Eugene Tremblay, 127 de la Ronde Street, Quebec City, P.Q., for the erection of a two-room day school with teacher's living quarters attached.

After construction commenced, it was found necessary to make certain changes, and as a consequence, extras in an amount of $6,802.72 were incurred. The following is an explanation of the extras.

1. The original estimate submitted by the company was evidently based on our plans which gave the levels. These plans did not take into consideration the depression of the land, and if the plans had been followed, the building would have been placed about three feet below road level, which was undesirable. To overcome this difficulty, we required extra cement, extra refill, extra lumber for forms and also extra labour.

2. In addition, it was found that the room originally shown on the plans as a coal bin would be required for a washroom for the Sisters in charge of the school, and also for Domestic Science purposes. Consequently, this required an exit to the outside. Extra plumbing for the toilet and wash basin was also required.
3. After construction commenced, it was found that there was a mistake in the plans, and as a result, new instructions were sent directly from the architect's office ordering the contractor to make certain changes. This involved changing the 2" x 4"'s to 2" x 6"'s, also the doubling of the plates and a change in spacing, which required considerably more material and labour.

The building has recently been completed, and an Engineer from the Department of Resources and Development reported on it in a memorandum dated April 12th, 1950, as follows:

"Structurally, both materials and workmanship are good. The sub-trades, plumbing, heating and electrical contracts, were carried out by competent firms and the installation of these facilities are very satisfactory. Certain local conditions that developed after the contract was awarded, necessitated changes being made in the original plans, and as a result, extras had to be allowed in order to meet the requirements. These extras have been carried out in a satisfactory manner, and the amount requested by the contractor for them is considered reasonable."

Memorandum to Council is enclosed.

Director.
Ottawa, May 17th, 1950.

Regarding the Minister's query respecting omissions in tenders being at the contractor's risk, it is felt that Mr. Harris should be advised that where a reputable contractor prepares an estimate, he is expected to have ability and knowledge to prepare it correctly, and after investigation and his assurance that all items are included, a department or government might be justified in limiting him to the amount of his estimate.

However, at Lorette, the successful contractor, Joseph Eugene Tremblay, was not a high-classed contractor and was obliged to prepare his tender without access to technical personnel for advice or comment regarding the peculiarities of the site and the method to be followed in adapting a typical design to an eccentric site. As a result, a bona fide error was only discovered when construction was well advanced. Since he was instructed to proceed following correction of his error, it is felt that he should receive consideration in connection with the resultant extra cost involved.

Where the necessary technical personnel is available to establish correct procedure in construction, tenders are examined and the contractor's methods and items explored before a contract is awarded. Since in this instance correct practice was not followed, we do not feel that the contractor should be penalized.

C. H. Buck,
Chief Engineer.
MEMORANDUM TO THE DEPUTY MINISTER.

Re: Lorette Indian Day School, Lorette Agency, Quebec.

Complete analysis of the matter covered by my memorandum to you under date of May 17th last, with reference to the above, has been delayed due to the absence from Ottawa on field duty of our Education Service Officer most familiar with the matter. The said officer, having recently returned, we have been able to discuss the matter with him, and the following comment is offered:

The Submission to Council, forwarded with my memorandum, seeks authority for our Minister to pay to Joseph Eugene Tremblay, the Contractor, extras beyond the limit of his contract to the amount of $6,802.72.

This school was one of the buildings for which our Education Service was forced to assume construction responsibility due to the volume of work upon which the Engineering and Construction Service, Department of Resources and Development, were engaged at the time supervisory assistance was badly needed by this Branch.

The contract had been awarded as the outcome of advertised invitations for tenders, and one of the contractor's obligations in tendering was to visit the site and acquaint himself with the conditions and difficulties that he might encounter in construction, one of which was to adapt a typical set of working drawings to the site.

The contractor evidently was not able, when tendering, to visualize that, to obtain solid bearings for his footings and, at the same time, place the main floor in the correct relation it should bear to the street, it would be necessary to increase the height of the foundation walls above that shown on the typical design, and the cost of the additional concrete required was not included in his tender. Construction had been initiated and most

Cont'd......
of the concrete had been poured when the correction was made, but there was no alternative to having the contractor carry the wall to the required height as an extra item. During the course of construction, approval was given for the installation of a small dispensary in the basement for the use of the Health Supervisor of the Department of National Health and Welfare, and further approval was given for the installation of laundry equipment to convert the original fuel storage room to a small laundry. Also, during construction, the contractor was authorized to change the heating system from coal to oil fuel, necessitating the installation of an oil burner. During this period, it was further decided to increase the size of structural timbers in the bearing partitions carrying the roof construction.

The school frame work had been completed and the building closed in before intermittent supervision by a Construction Supervisor from Resources and Development was available.

All of these changes involved revisions to water lines, electric wiring and drainage; and the combined cost of all items, amounting to $6,802.72, is considered reasonable by our own recently appointed Engineering staff. I might say that the cost involved in providing a dispensary for the Health Supervisor will be recovered from the Department of National Health and Welfare.

As building operations progressed, and the various items involving extras arose, authorization should have been obtained and the increases in cost brought to the attention of our Treasury officials with written evidence of approval from the proper source. This would have eliminated the necessity of securing the approval of Council for a total expenditure beyond the limit of our Minister's authority.

However, funds are available and, as the charges are legitimate, there appears no alternative to obtaining authority to pay them. Work on the school, including the extras, has been completed in a satisfactory manner, and a Certificate of Acceptance has been issued by the previously-mentioned Supervisor of Construction.

Cont'd......
It is recommended, therefore, that the Submission dated May 17th, 1950, and already signed by our Minister, be forwarded for action by Council. The copies you returned to Mr. Buck are attached hereto.

The fill and finished grading necessitated by the peculiarities of the site are not part of Tremblay's contract, and tenders are presently being invited from properly equipped contractors for that final phase of operations.

Acting Director.

Re: Site treatment and landscaping - Indian Day School, Lorette Agency, Quebec.

Forwarded herewith are duplicate copies of a brief report with estimate of cost, and a tracing of a rough sketch showing proposed grading work required for the above, but which was not included in the contract for building the school.

The tracing is taken from Mr. Goedike's original rough sketch, and may be retained for your files. Mr. Doucet should obtain blueprints in sufficient numbers to supply copies to parties tendering on the work.

Please note that the estimated cost of fill in place is $696.00. Gravel for walks is estimated at $10.50.

It is felt that, to maintain the terracing formed by the fill, sodding should be carried out. This item will be, by a large measure, the most expensive phase of the operations. OTTAWA, June 14, 1950.

REPORT ON LORETTÉ RESERVATION SCHOOL

Lorette school has been completed, the contractor having made a first-class job and could be released from contract and final payment made.

Dear Sir:

My Indians, young and old, wish very much to learn reading and writing in the Micmac language. The teacher being unable to teach them in this language, they would like a Restigouche Indian named Nicolas Jerome, who is well up in this dialect, to give them lessons for a month or two at the most. Sir,

Referring to your letter of June 18th, file 154179-1, respecting charges of misconduct made against Miss Isaac, teacher of Maria school, I beg to report that upon the day it was received notifications were sent to the complainant the Rev. J.D. Morin, Indian Agent and to Miss Isaac that an investigation would be held on the 24th or 25th of June and that they should be prepared for it.

On the former date at 3 P.M. the investigation was commenced. The Agent was absent assigning a very regrettable cause, stated in the letter appended hereto. In view of what he says in that letter it did not appear that he was essential to the inquiry so it was decided to dispense with his attendance. There are two other points in this letter to which attention is directed. John Martin and the Chief are said to have been notified and

F. Pedley, Esq

Deputy Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs.
there is in the last sentence a complete admission that he has been making most damaging representations without personal knowledge of their truth. When this is contrasted with the positive statements he has made against Miss Isaac in his letters to the Department indignation goes hand in hand with surprise. When the Department pointed out to him that the charges and insinuations made by him were vague he replied "You should trust me being also an officer of the Department, Indian Agent, Justice of the Peace and a Priest. My words and reports are right and just and true."

Appended hereto is a minute of the proceedings and the evidence taken. It had to be decided whether to proceed in the absence of the two witnesses said to be material viz., John Martin and Peter Caplin. It was decided to proceed as they could have been present had they so desired and their representative the Agent advised that they were not notified.

Reference to the minute and evidence shows that all the Indians present but one were favourable to Miss Isaac and flatly contradicted the statement that the majority of the band ever wished her to be removed. Reference to the petition on file received by the Department on April 22nd bears this out as it is signed by eleven out of

This one was not adverse but simply "knew nothing"
eighteen of the band.

The witness, Mrs Susan Martin, betrayed strong animus, yet her evidence contains nothing that seems to be damaging. As to the time once spent by Edward Martin with Miss Isaac she is contradicted by Miss Isaac and by Edward Martin. The latter is married to Miss Isaac's cousin and she is now living with them. Mrs Martin who is a very respectable woman, scouts all idea of impropriety and no doubt does so very properly.

I think Miss Isaac is free from blame for obtaining a small bottle of gin for Mrs Martin. It was supplied under the prescription of a medical man in January 1907 over two years ago. The certificate forms Exhibit 1. Miss Isaac's mother procured the gin. Miss Isaac took it to the reserve to the sick woman as asked. She swears that she never on any other occasion obtained an intoxicant for an Indian.

The making of this charge now concerning a matter of such old date and one in respect of which there never seems to have been any concealment is rather a testimony favourable to Miss Isaac as it shows how far her assailants had to go in their attempt to make a case against her.

The reply to the Martin complaint that his child has never learned to sign her name is Susan Martin's signature at the head of page 4.
The boy Thomas Dedam refers to as his child, is Abraham Caplin (adopted). Dedam says that this boy does not know the A.B.C. Abraham Caplin's signature is on page 4. The statement that he does not know the alphabet is not true. He repeated it to me with facility.

I found nine boys and seven girls in attendance on my arrival, examined them and found their performances very fair. Miss Isaac showed me the last report of the School Inspector. I endorse what he said.

I conclude that there is nothing whatever in these charges and it is astonishing that the Indian Agent should have adopted the attitude he has. He might have caused the ruin of a young girl who seems to be of the highest worth and to have done this in view of the admission that he has no knowledge of the facts, constitutes an offence that cannot, in my opinion, be too strongly censured.

I trust the Department will see its way to condemn such conduct, and to inform Miss Isaac that she is entirely vindicated.

Your obedient servant,

I.I.A. & R.

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, transmitting a communication addressed to you by the Rev. J. P. Morin recommending the engagement of Miss Josephine Audet, of Maria, as teacher of the Indian School at that place.

In reply I beg to say that the Department had already received an application from Miss Audet for this position, but, as she is the holder of only an Elementary Diploma granted her in the year 1867, it communicated with Mr. G. Marquis, Inspector of Schools, Quebec, asking him to be good enough to suggest the name of a qualified teacher for this school. He recommended Miss Jeanne Loubert, of Campbellton, N.B., who is the holder of a Model School Diploma, and the Department offered her the position on the 3rd instant. She has not yet notified the Department of her acceptance and if she does not do so by the 14th instant it is prepared to engage Miss Audet.

Yours very truly,

Hon. Charles Maccoll,
Speaker,
House of Commons,

March 14th, 1916.

Sir,

I have received your letter dated March 13th, 1916, stating that the Indians here are in favor of the Indians here acting for the appointment of Miss Rita Gordon as teacher here in place of Miss Josephine Carter who has been refused by the Department and have brought your letter (copy of which I received from your office) to the notice of those Indians who signed the petition.

In reply to your letter they today that we are not satisfied with Miss Audet and wish her being kept on as teacher and we still want Miss Gordon to be appointed in her place. We take great interest in our school here and we have about 22 scholars attending and we want them to have the best teaching possible which we do not consider that Miss Audet is able to give them. I will give you some reasons for what I have said.

Miss Audet has been teaching here for 6 years past.
and Mrs. Gideon is not able to teach the children the Catechism in their own language but only in English which they do not understand sufficiently to learn the Catechism properly as shown by the fact that only 3 children have made their first Communion during that year. Father Pacific our missionary examined the children last April and he stated then that the children were not properly taught and knew almost nothing. He said they should be taught the Catechism in their own language so that they would learn it more quickly and he asked Miss Rita Gideon to do this and since then she has been teaching the children for no salary in her own home of an evening. Again Miss Gideon is not so well qualified to teach in any subject as Miss Gideon because Miss Gideon only holds a low diploma which she obtained about 20 years ago when the standard of education was not nearly as high as that required now. Miss Gideon, on the other hand only obtained her diplomas last year and she holds a 1st class Model diploma in English and 1st class French Elementary diploma, and she passed her examinations "with distinction." Miss Gideon was educated at Carleton College and is a good musician and typewriter. Again Miss Gideon can get a school among the white people while Miss Gideon having been
raised an Indian. Now we would have difficulty doing so and we think that considering the expenses her parents have been at and the trouble she has taken to obtain her education and her diploma being so much better and more recent than Miss Gideon's it is not fairing her fairly to give the Indian school here to a white teacher while Miss Gideon has no school. We would also point out that if the Department insist upon Miss Gideon as teacher after we have given good reason against it there is likely to be trouble among the Indians here as many of them will not send their children to the school. We would also point out that Father Ross our Agent here would naturally favor Miss Gideon because she is related to him and the Inspector would naturally be inclined to agree with the Agent. But we are only desirous in bringing this matter before the Department that the best shall be done in the interest of our children. Having thus educated to the best advantage and having this feeling we know and are satisfied that this purpose will be best served by having Miss Gideon appointed as Teacher here and therefore we ask that the Department will grant our request in this matter or at any rate that the Department before refusing to appoint Miss Gideon will call the opinion of Father Pacific our missionary.
Who has the true interest of the Indians at heart and who we feel sure will be in favor of Mrs. Gideon.

Has also complained against Mrs. Gideon because she interferes in the affairs of the Nez Perce which is no part of her duty but should be done by our Agent. She has been in the habit of keeping the school open after 4 p.m. and selling goods, hats, face powder, ribbon, and other things at excessive prices to the Indians for her own benefit. Also card playing and dances are strictly forbidden amongst us and Mrs. Gideon has on several occasions encouraged Indians here to do these things in their houses. Also she has made concerts and used K. School house for that purpose without proper authority first obtained.

Hoping that the Department will hold full inquiry into this matter and grant the wishes of the Indians and requesting an early reply.

I am Sir,

Your obedient Servant

James Johnson

MEMORANDUM:

Acting Deputy Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs,

Mr. Agent Leblanc states that Miss Josephine Audet,
teacher of the Maria Indian Day School, desires to give up
her position as teacher provided she is granted super-
annuation or a pension. He requests that in view of her
long service, and as she is getting old, that she be granted
some assistance.

There is no provision for the granting of superannuation
or pensions to teachers of Indian day schools, but a gratuity
on retirement has been granted in the cases of several teachers
in the past.

Miss Audet began duties at this school February 21, 1910,
at a salary of $300, which was increased to $350 on July 1,
1910, and to $400 on September 1, 1912, and to $450, her
present salary, on July 1, 1916. During the last three years
she has also received the bonus allowed teachers at the rate
of $150 per annum. She has a diploma for the teaching of
French and English, and the Inspector has invariably reported
that her services are satisfactory.

The Department has, in the past, granted gratuities in
several cases, as follows:

In 1909, Mrs. C. A. Vollick, who had taught the No. 3
School on the Oneida Reserve for a period of 17 years and
who resigned on account of failing health, was granted a
gratuity of $100.00, in recognition of her long and faithful
service. The salary allowed her at that time was at the
rate of $300.00 per annum.

A gratuity was granted Miss Annie Kehoe, teacher of the
Goulais Bay Indian Day School, in June, 1915. Miss Kehoe
was in the service of the Department for eight years. She
contracted tuberculosis from her work among the Indians.
In addition to teaching, she acted as field matron and visited
and attended the sick on the two reserves on which she had
taught. The Department allowed her a gratuity equal to one
quarter of her yearly salary, or total of $125.00.

L. F. Hardiman, teacher of the Anglican School on the
Garden River Reserve, after completing 30 years of service
as a teacher in Indian Schools, was granted a gratuity equal
to six months' salary (March 31, 1919). The amount paid him
was $300.00.

In November, last, Mr. John R. Lickers, teacher of the No.
5 School on the Six Nations Reserve, retired after 35 years'
service as a teacher in Indian Schools. He was allowed
a gratuity of six months' salary, which amounted to $350.00.

- In May -
In May, 1921, a gratuity equal to one quarter salary was granted Miss Jeannie McDermott, assistant teacher at the Garden River (R.C.) Indian Day School, who had been in the employ of the Department for a period of 13 years.

The Agent states that Miss Audet is in very poor health, and is willing to retire provided she gets some assistance.

I would recommend, in view of her faithful service, and in view of the fact that she is compelled on account of her health to retire, also that it is impossible for a teacher to save any money on the salary paid her, that the Department allow her a gratuity on her retirement equal to at least one quarter of her yearly salary, which, in her case, would amount to $112.50. This could be paid from the appropriation for Indian education as was done in all the above mentioned cases.
