Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 25th instant, requesting that superannuation or a pension be granted Miss Josephine Audet, teacher of the Maria Indian Day School, and stating that, if this were granted, she would give up duties.

Dr. Scott,

With reference to the attached papers concerning Miss Josephine Audet, I have to report that she gave this Department 13 years' service as a teacher of the Maria Indian Day School in Quebec. When she resigned, on account of ill health, she was allowed retiring leave equivalent to 3 months' salary. The Right Honourable W.L. MacKenzie King,
OTTAWA.

Honourable Sir,

While hesitating to bother you during a time when you must be engrossed in political affairs, I wish to take this opportunity of laying my claim before you prior to your visit abroad.

I have spent twenty-eight years of my life as a teacher. For four years I taught in the United States, for twelve years in various parts of the Province of Quebec and for a further period of twelve years I was the teacher on the Indian Reservation situated between this village and Cascapedia.

Approximately five years ago I was obliged to discontinue this work as a result of ill health. I have every reason to believe that I gave satisfaction in the posts to which I was assigned, a statement which any investigation would serve to prove.

My work among the Indians was unusually arduous. As a rule the hours were very considerably longer than in the ordinary provincial school. A great deal of extra work was involved during my association with the Indians and not only was the necessity of begging for them added to my regular duties, but upon occasion I assisted the Indian children with funds from my own purse.

Whereas my health precludes the possibility of my ever renewing my work as a teacher and in view of my past record, I feel that the Government might consider granting me a pension, or some alternative, but adequate compensation for my past services.

I would ask you, therefore, to give my request your earnest and personal consideration and, if necessary, forward my claim to such Minister of your Government who may have these matters in hand.

Thanking you in anticipation of your courtesy regarding this matter and assuring you of my gratification at your success during the recent election, believe me to be, sir,

Your obedient servant

Josephine Audet

Honourable Sir,

If you would be good enough to have your Secretary refer to your files, you will find that just prior to the time that you sailed for England, I wrote to you with reference to obtaining a pension for my many years of service as a teacher in this vicinity.

In this connection your Secretary advised me that you had instructed him to refer the matter to the Honourable Charles Stewart. A few weeks ago I received a letter from the Deputy Superintendent of the Department of Indian Affairs advising me that there is no way in which it is possible that I can be granted any pension, or anything other than the three months salary I received upon retiring.

Although I do not wish in any way to criticise any action which your ministers may see fit to take, it seems to me that the decision reached by the Deputy Superintendent is a most unjust one.

May I so far bother you as to ask you to have the matter looked into a little more deeply? It would seem to me that the statement that "there is no way in which it is possible----" is somewhat arbitrary.

The education of Indians is a form of teaching service somewhat outside the realms of ordinary education and the average teachers' experience. Not only is this true of the amount of patience and sympathetic understanding demanded, but also as regards the number of hours work entailed, the necessity, as I have already pointed out, of continually begging for them, and the constant demands upon my private purse.

My many years of service, coupled with my present poor state of health as a result of such service, leads me to feel

Memorandum:

DR. SCOTT.

With further reference to the complaint in the letter of Anthony Martin, of the Maria Reserve, after a study of our files, I am inclined to the opinion that this Indian is not expressing the thoughts of many of his people. The Maria Indian Day School, which is taught by Miss Dora Gedeon, 27 year old Indian girl, is well attended and no other complaints have reached the Department. This teacher possesses an Elementary Teacher's Diploma (French and English) for Quebec and has taught at this school during the past 9½ years. The Provincial School Inspectors who visit the school regularly have reported very favourably.

It is entirely probable that Miss Gedeon is not a really good teacher as she possesses the minimum qualifications. I find that the School Inspectors' reports, because of their brevity, do not paint a very good picture of this worker. The average attendance of over 20 pupils at this school for the past few years suggests that the teacher is doing fairly good work.

Sir—On March 3rd, 1932, I had the opportunity of visiting the Maria Indian Day School, in company with school Inspector Mr. Leblanc.

We found 17 girls and 15 boys at school, out of a possible 36 of school age. The inspection was fairly reliable to get an idea of the teaching they were receiving, and the inspector told me he was satisfied they were getting well instructed.

The children I thought answered much quicker and better when the teacher questioned them, and I suggested to the Inspector that we might get a better idea of what they knew, if he allowed the teacher to question them in all the different branches of study, and for him to make his suggestions to her.

They were not accustomed to his manner and he could not understand them well. In my opinion they knew a lot more than he could make them demonstrate. He agreed that at his next visit he would try out my suggestion, and I expect to be present to see the result.

Your advice is always appreciated.

Yours truly,

Ottawa, Sept. 14, 1938.

Sir,

I beg to submit a report of my Inspection of the Maria Agency made on the 22nd August, 1938.

Before leaving the reserve, I visited the Constable, Milton Gideon, and told him of all the complaints received at the school meeting.

The conclusion in this matter is that the whole thing is a family quarrel; on one side, Constable Gedeon, on the other side, the teacher, Miss Gedeon, his own sister, and a couple of his brothers. As a Constable, Gedeon trying to accomplish his duties to the best of his ability is not popular. The fact that Agent Cyr, who lives a few miles away from the Reserve, has to depend a great deal on Constable Gedeon living on the Reserve is quite natural, but many of the Indians do not seem to approve of it, nor understand it.

I have never seen brothers and sisters so divided and bitter, one alone having to stand against all others combined. No one seems to be willing to stop this feud and those against the Constable appear to have stirred the majority of the Indians against their own brother. I will not believe that this man is as bad as he is supposed to be until someone can prove it to me. This is the most bitter family affair I have ever seen. There may be faults on both sides, but the only solution I can see would be to put them all out of jobs and appoint a new teacher and a new constable.

Jude Thibault,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, Sept. 14, 1938.

Sir,

I beg to submit a report of my Inspection of the Maria Agency made on August 22nd, 1938.

After the usual opening remarks, I asked if there were anyone who wished to voice any suggestions, complaints, etc., and the following is an outline of such.

Chief Councillor Isaac Martin informed me that the Constable is not helping the Indians to have their children attend school and he is not trying to help the Chief and Councillors. He also wanted to know why the Constable always interfered between the Indians and the Agent. Constable Gedson has been trying to have the school teacher dismissed, saying that the Indians requested such a move. However, the Chief stated they had nothing to say against the teacher. On the subject of education, he pointed out that the school house was too small; there was no room for more desks and at the present time have to seat three on a seat provided for two. He complained that the Councillors were never informed of what was going on - neither from the Agent or from the Constable.

Dear Sir:

Referring to my message of the 19th of this month, I beg to expose the following facts: I have been discussing lately with Mr. Jackson of your department about the Indian Reserve of Maria. We both admitted that there is something to do in that reserve if we want to improve the conditions in which Indians live and decrease the cost of direct relief. Firstly, I want to recommend, after having consulted the authorities of the Reserve, the bishop, the priest, the chief, the agent, the police, to engage English speaking nuns to teach at the school instead of Miss Dora Gedeon and Adigh LeBlanc.

You know that the Indians of the Reserve of Maria are Catholics. His Excellency Bishop Ross has appointed two sisters from the congregation of the St. Rosary, Rimouski, namely, Sister Mary of Mercy and Sister Mary of St. Daniel.

In the last years, the authorities of Maria have been anxious to get nuns to teach at the Indian School and I personally know that the whole matter has been exposed to your department since two years; therefore, I ask you to accept my proposition to get in touch with the above mentioned Sisters and to engage them at once as official teachers in the Indian School of Maria. They have the qualifications and diploma required.

Now before the school opens, I recommend certain improvements in the school: School has been wired but the electricity is not connected yet, beside that I ask for the instalment of a bathroom and the digging of a well to secure water to the school.
Secondly: If we want to decrease the cost of direct relief in the Reserve of Maria, I believe that we should give the official authority to the parish priest of Maria as it was in the old days. So I would recommend if there is any change to be made at the Reserve that Father Edmond Plourde, parish priest of Maria be appointed as official Indian Agent with the salary of $300.00 a year and that the actual agent, Mr. Napoleon Cyr be appointed assistant Indian Agent and farming instructor with the salary of $600.00 a year. Mr. Cyr would devote all his time to the Indians; he would make them cut their wood and cultivate a garden vegetables and potatoes and by and by keep a cow and a pig.

I saw Mr. Cyr myself and Father Edmond Plourde and all the authorities of Maria, the major, the Indian chief, the police and they are all enthusiastic about that plan. The bishop himself, Mgr. Ross is greatly in favour of this plan and thinks a lot of it. He is ready to support my proposition and we all believe that after a few years you will see yourself lots of improvements in that Reserve.

Hoping that you will accept my proposition, I remain,

Yours truly,

J. Alphe Poirier, M. P.

Dear Mr. Poirier:

I desire to refer to your telegram of the 11th instant with reference to the teaching services at the Maria Indian Day School.

In our appropriation for the current fiscal year it was only found possible to provide the funds required for the operation of Indian day schools for a nine-month period instead of ten months. The lay teachers who were in charge of the school during the academic year 1939-40, and whose employment was continued for 1940-41, had sufficient interest in their work to write to the Department and state that they were willing to operate the school for the full ten-month period, even though they would only be paid for nine months. The Department appreciated this action on their part and they were consequently authorized to re-open the school.

While the Department has no objection to the employment of Nuns as teachers of the Maria School, at the same time I feel you will agree that we should deal fairly with the two lay teachers. It would not be fair to dismiss them without giving them adequate notice as it would be practically impossible for them to secure other schools at the present time, due to the fact that school boards have already secured teachers for the academic year 1940-41.

The desirability of employing Nuns to take charge of the Maria School will be given careful consideration by the officials of this Branch and a definite decision reached in respect to the matter prior to the opening of the 1941-42 academic year.

The Reverend Father Placide replied in a letter dated August 7, 1889, stating that it was impossible for His Excellency Bishop Ross to secure Sisters to take charge of the Maria School. This is the only correspondence on file relating to the employment of Nuns to take charge of the Maria School.

In your letter you express the opinion that the Department should have given the teachers 30 days' notice of dismissal, when you communicated with us at the end of August. May I point out that a number of court decisions have been given with respect to the employment of public school teachers, indicating that during the holiday period - which usually consists of the months of July and August - teachers are not actually in the employment of a school, nor are Indian day school teachers during these months in the employment of the Government. Consequently, notice could only be given from the first of October, which is the first teaching month in the present academic year. In the case of public school teachers, in the majority of the provinces notice can only be given on the first day of June of each year or 30 days prior to the Christmas vacation. I feel confident you will agree with me that the Dominion Government as an employer of labour should not lend itself to any action that would create a sense of injustice in the minds of the teachers whose -

You will, I feel sure, readily appreciate the position in which the officials of this Branch find themselves. It is their duty and responsibility to interpret the regulations governing the employment of teachers that are approved by the Minister from time to time.

Memorandum for file:

Re Maria Agency

Mr. Pratt and I discussed with Messrs. Hoey, Thibault, Arneil and Morris, the situation at this Agency, for the purpose of determining what steps should be taken either in the appointment of an Agent or to combine this Agency with the Restigouche Agency.

All of the officials in the Branch expressed the view that the situation at Maria had not changed for a good many years past and that the Indians were of a very low class. Mr. Hoey expressed the opinion that there had been no improvement in them for the last twenty or twenty-five years. I suggested to him that the money spent on their education had hardly been worth while because those children educated fifteen or twenty years ago should by this time have shown some of the results of the money that was spent on them. I pointed out that recently we had spent over $10,000 on a new school and that if the Indians were not getting any benefit from the education we were giving them, perhaps some consideration should be given to making a change in the activities carried on in the school.

It was suggested that perhaps more time should be devoted to teaching the Indians manual training and how to grow gardens. At the present time there are two female teachers in the school, a Miss Gideon who has been there for a number of years, and a younger girl who was appointed more recently. They do not teach any manual training. It was decided that Mr. Hoey should communicate with Macdonald College for the purpose of ascertaining whether there are any young graduates from that College who came from the Maria district and who might be interested in accepting a position of teacher at this school if the salary were increased.
It was thought that it might be possible to combine the positions of teacher and Agent and in this way the administrative costs of the Agency would not be increased very much. Arrangements could be made with Acting Agent Cyr to engage his services and equipment during the summer months to assist the Teacher-Agent in carrying out his instruction work.

It is of course appreciated that no change of this nature could be put into effect until the end of the school term. In the meantime it was decided to allow Mr. Cyr to continue as Acting Agent. It was decided that he should be written to fully, suggesting that steps should be taken immediately spring arrives to plow up as much land as possible, up to 30 acres, and an endeavour made to get the Indians to put this new land into gardens.

No definite decision was reached in reference to the Restigouche Agency. It was generally the consensus of opinion that it would be advisable to have a new Agent appointed there in place of Dr. Richard, allowing the latter to continue with the medical work.

C.W. Jackson

Chief Executive Assistant.

DEPUTY MINISTER.

Re: Maria Indian Day School - Maria, Bonaventure Co., Que.

I am sending forward herewith, for your information, copy of a telegram received by me from J. Alplee Poirier, M.D., Member for Bonaventure, Que. The subject matter of this telegram, you will note, is self-explanatory.

An attempt has been made since then to secure a young man, qualified not only to take charge of the regular classroom work but to supervise the agricultural program on the reserve. It was our hope that by the employment of a man such as this the present agent could act as farming instructor and work under the teacher's direction.

The Superintendent of Welfare and Training informs me that he has interviewed Mr. Lefebvre, of the Civil Service Commission, and an official of the rural teachers' organization of Quebec, with the object of securing a suitable man, and that both these gentlemen have promised to assist in this task.

It may be remembered that Mr. Poirier made an attempt to secure Sisters for this school last year. In view of the fact, however, that it was considered undesirable to dismiss the regular teachers then in charge, without notice, no change in the teaching staff was made. Dear Mr. McGill,

I have just learned indirectly that the Department was seeking a lay teacher for the school of the Indian Reserve of Maria. It is claimed that he would also instruct the Indians in farming and would assume the supervision of the school gardens. It is indeed childish; when one knows the mentality of the Indians, one knows that they will turn a deaf ear to the teaching of the theory of agriculture.

I was under the impression that your Department had agreed, last fall, to entrust, next September, the Indian school of Maria to the Sisters of the Holy Rosary.

Has not Bishop Ross made an official request in this connection?

The religious and civil authorities of the county have reached an agreement in order to entrust the children of the Maria Indian Reserve to the Sisters.

We have tried several other experiments, but unsuccessfully. Please let us try this last one. I do not see how your Department would be justified to interfere with our projects in this connection.

Be that as it may, I wish to state clearly that I do not endorse the appointment of a lay teacher, and if this matter is not settled to the satisfaction of the parties concerned, I wish to warn you that I will bring up the matter before the House of Commons.

According to the interested parties in the county, the best solution to this problem would be as follows; the civil and religious authorities hold the same views in this respect. After all, we are not under a dictatorship in this country and the views of the member of the constituency, when they are supported by the local civil and religious authorities, should have some weight.
As agricultural instructor, I would suggest that you appoint the present Indian Agent, Mr. Napoléon Cyr. Mr. Cyr exerts a certain authority over the Indians. He is a good worker, a fairly progressive farmer and he will be able to put them to work. If you are willing to increase his salary to $500 per year, he will devote all his time to this work during the summer, spring and fall.

You could appoint as agent Father Plourde, of Maria, who has been the Indians' parish priest since last fall; being a founder of settlers' parishes, he knows how to economize and I am sure that he would make a success of such an undertaking. Appoint him on probation for a year or two and if he does not save you enough money to enable you to pay his salary, you could replace him.

Entrust the school to the Sisters of the Holy Rosary, and within ten years, I am sure that enormous progress will be accomplished from the standpoint of moral, education and instruction.

I would urge you to consider the above suggestions seriously.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) J. Alphée Poirier,
M.P. for Bonaventure.

Dear Sir,

On the twenty-first of August 1940, Mr. J. Alphée Poirier, M.P., for Bonaventure addressed to Mr. Harold McKell, Director of your Department a letter in which he argued the great necessity of having Sisters of the Holy Rosary of Rimouski in charge of the Maria Indian Reserve School. This intervention of his came after conversations held on the subject with the authorities of the Reserve namely the Chief, the Agent and the Constable, the whole with my full approval. As stated in that letter, all the Indians in that Reserve are Catholics, and it is their utmost desire to have nuns in charge of their school to instruct and educate their children; they are aware of how the same question is dealt with in the Ristigouche Reserve where a group of the same race is highly satisfied with the work of the Reverend Sisters.

On September the eleventh the same Mr. Poirier wired to your Department to urge the carrying out of his request; on the sixteenth of the same month you answered thus: "The Department has no objection to the employment of nuns as teachers in the Maria School", asking at the same time that the whole affair be delayed in order to give the teachers then in charge a fair dealing; you then declared that the question shall be solved before the opening of the 1941-1942 school year.

Trusting in those declarations I advised Mr. Poirier not to insist to have nuns in charge for the classical year 1940-1941.

Before the present academical year comes to an end, here am I to join with Mr. Poirier in asking you to manage so as to have the Sisters of the Holy Rosary duly in charge of the school in the Maria Indian Reserve for the coming academical year of 1941-1942.

I have just read the letter addressed to Mr. McKell on the fifteenth instant by Mr. Poirier, and I beg to state that I fully endorse his request and that I rely on him to have the matter carried out satisfactorily.

In the meantime I beg to remain, Mr. Secretary,

Yours very truly,

Re: Maria Indian Day School.

My dear Bishop Ross:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of April 17, in which you submit for departmental consideration a request that the Sisters of the Holy Rosary of Rimouski be placed in charge of the Maria Indian Day School.

I may state that immediately following certain representations made to this Branch by Mr. J. Alpheo Poirier, M.P., to which you refer in your communication, a great deal of consideration was given to conditions at the Maria Indian Reserve, the welfare of the Indian population and an agricultural program that might be promoted on the reserve lands and also the instruction that might be provided at the school.

The Maria Reserve has, according to the last census, a population of 282 Indians, practically all of whom have been in recent years in receipt of relief. Relief costs in the province of Quebec for the fiscal year 1939-40 amounted to $16.52 per head of Indian population as against relief costs of $4.62 in the province of Ontario and $4.59 in the province of British Columbia. The records indicate that, with the exception of a small group of Indians in the Maritime Provinces, relief costs in the province of Quebec are the highest in the Dominion. In view of this fact, a decision was reached a few weeks ago to promote a worthwhile agricultural program on the Maria Reserve. It was decided at

Right Reverend P. X. Ross, D.D.,
Bishop of Gaspe,
Gaspe, Que.
that time, in view of all the circumstances, that a male teacher should be placed in charge of the senior room. It was our thought that a male teacher could give general supervision to a welfare program on the reserve and organize at the school a program of manual training, emphasizing woodwork, elementary auto mechanics, elementary blacksmithing, etc. This decision was reached in view of the fact that there is an actual shortage in Canada today of skilled workers on the one hand while we have actually thousands of unskilled workers out of employment, on the other. It is our feeling that educational authorities cannot fully escape responsibility for this condition.

A telegram dated April 15, 1941, and a letter of the same date, received by this Branch from Mr. Poirier - both asking for the employment of Sisters as teachers at the Maria School, have been sent forward to the Minister for his consideration. It is just possible that conditions at Maria will again be reviewed in the immediate future, and I can assure you that the request you have made will be carefully considered when the matter comes up for discussion.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

We, the Indians of the Maria Indian Reserve, are painfully surprised to see that Miss Dora Bidion, who has been our teacher since nineteen years, is not allowed to hold her position any longer. Sisters are now in charge of our school. Nobody warned us of the new change. All the Indians of Maria Reserve, by this letter, are hereby protesting and asking the Department to replace Miss Bidion as teacher of the primary grades. We judge it very unjust to take from Miss Bidion, without any reason, her only means of earning a living, after nineteen years of devotion to the education of our children. Here are our main reasons for protesting against such an act, that is unjust on the part...
of the Department.

1st Miss Dora Gideon is one of our own; she was born and brought up on the Reserve. The Department should favor the teachers of the Reserve before strangers.

2nd The Department paid Miss Gideon's instruction; why not now see that she makes good use of it? Miss Gideon is one of the rare Indian teachers that has made excellent use of her instruction.

3rd Since Miss Gideon is teaching, she has paid the college course of one of her brothers who is a priest today, teaching in one of the classical colleges of Quebec. Miss Gideon has also paid for two of her sisters in convent, and a brother at the high school. Almost all her earnings went for education of her brothers and sisters.

4th Miss Gideon is now without parents. Her father died in 1927, her mother in 1939. Since her father's death, Dora was the only support to her mother and home. Is it just to not to consider all these factors before discharging Miss Gideon. She has no fortune in reserve; during her nineteen
years of service she has always been a supporter of the home and family.

We, the Indians of Maria Reserve, are sending a copy of this letter to the Very Honorable Ernest Lapointe, Minister of Justice, begging him to judge the case, plead our cause, and give us a favorable answer. Ottawa, February 3, 1945.

Rev. Sister Mary of Mercy, Principal, Maria Day School,
Dimock Creek, Que.

I have your letter of the 21st instant,
with reference to the salary of Sister Mary of the
Sacred Heart.

Several months ago a ruling was made
to the effect that a member of a religious Order, whose
salary is usually turned over in total to the Order
to which she belongs is not subject to income tax.
A further ruling was made to the effect that when
income tax is not being paid the bonus cannot be allowed.

In the case of Sister Mary of the Sacred
Heart, her basic salary was $60.00 and through over-
sight she was allowed bonus at the rate of $10.20 for
the month of September, making her total salary $70.20.
From this amount $4.50 was deducted for income tax and
$3.00 for the Retirement Fund, leaving a net amount
payable to her of $62.70. This payment was adjusted
in October and November, and, as a result, Sister Mary
of the Sacred Heart received a basic salary of $60.00
without bonus and without deduction for income tax
or payment to the retirement fund. This meant that
she was simply paid her basic salary and consequently
she received $60.00 for October and November. The $3.00
deducted for the month of September for the Retirement
Fund was refunded to her on November 8, 1944. I realize
this is a rather involved explanation. There is no
desire on our part to bring her salary lower than she
originally thought it would be, but, at the same time,
in view of the regulations regarding members of a
religious Order, no other action could be taken. It has been decided to increase the salary of this Sister by $5.00 a month, effective February 1, 1945.

To date, I believe no decision has been taken in this regard. As far as I am concerned, I have received no written order from the Department in the matter, but I know on the other hand that it is against the Department's regulations to accept white pupils in the Indian schools without preliminary arrangements.

The Chief of the Reserve, John B. Jérôme, has ordered the Superior to expel all the white pupils (and this was done) although the chief has not made any complaint to me in this regard since the beginning of September. Since this order was not issued by the Department, I had the families asked to send back their children to the school until further notice.

Will you kindly submit this letter to the school trustees at your first meeting of this month and take a decision with regard to these pupils. As far as I am concerned, I believe it is useless to submit an amount of less than $50.00 per year per family.

This amount could be paid out in whatever manner you may deem adequate, either fully by the School Commission or in part by the families concerned.

Will you kindly let me have an immediate report on your decision so that I may forward it to the Department for approval.

INSPECTION REPORT

MARIA Indian Day School

Date of Inspection - September 6, 1949.

Location of School:

This school is located on the north shore of the Restigouche River opposite the town of Dalhousie, N.B. It is on the south Gaspe coast of the Province of Quebec. There is a good road immediately in front of the school and the nearby village of MARIA has the usual village stores. This school is not isolated in any sense of the term.

Type of School:

This is a standard two-room school with attached teachers' residence. It is furnace-heated with full basement. There are adequate facilities for manual training and domestic science teaching in the basement. It is lighted throughout and the building is in good condition.

Teachers:

Both teachers are qualified and certificated.

The teachers are:

Sister St. Bernadine

Sister Mary of the Divine Heart.

The senior room has Grades 5, 6 and 7. These children tested well and I was able to give the teacher considerable help in the way of vocabulary work and the proper use of workbooks.

(recommendations)
RECOMMENDATIONS:

(1) This school needs painting outside and paint has already been ordered.

(2) Running toilets could be installed next year.

(3) Some consideration should be given to the appointment of a truant officer.

(4) Road signs should be installed.

(5) A provincial inspection should be arranged.

(6) A fence can be erected at a later date.

(7) The sewer should be re-directed to provide a further down slope.

(8) Both teachers should be reminded concerning the necessity of attending Summer Schools.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Ottawa, August 19, 1922.

Madam:

Replying to your letter of the 13th instant, I beg to say that we have been unable to get any trace of the cheque which was mailed you on the 7th of July last for your salary for the June quarter as Teacher of the Maria Indian Day School. The Post Office Department have been unable to trace the letter enclosing this cheque. Our mailing book shows that this cheque was mailed to you, addressed to Maria, Que., on July 7th, last.

Before we can issue a duplicate cheque, it will be necessary for you to furnish a bond of indemnity for double the amount of the cheque, and this bond should be signed by two responsible persons, as sureties. You will, no doubt, be able to secure two of your friends who will go on this bond.

We are enclosing forms of bond of indemnity, which we have filled in as far as our information goes. It will be necessary for you and the persons who go on the bond as your sureties to appear before a justice of the peace, or a notary public, who should fill in the remaining blanks, where required. This bond should be signed by yourself and the two sureties, in the presence of a subscribing witness. The sureties and the witness to the signature should make the declarations required before a justice of the peace.

When these documents have been properly executed, they should be returned to the Department, and a duplicate cheque will be sent you. The Auditor General requires that before duplicate cheques are issued, a proper bond of indemnity be obtained from the party to whom the cheque was made payable, in order to prevent loss to the Government, should the original cheque turn up at any time and be cashed.

We regret the inconvenience you are put to, but would advise that you have this bond of indemnity completed as soon as possible and returned to the Department, when a duplicate of the lost cheque will be sent you.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Mclean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Miss Doris Geddes,
Dimock Creek,
Que.

Department of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir,

On September 30th last, I forwarded the quarterly report of the Maria Indian Day School.

I do not understand why I should not receive the same sum this year, for 1923 September quarter, as report was made for the three months, July, August and September. Ottawa, October 18, 1923.

Enclosure.

Madam,-

In reply to your letter of the 15th instant, I beg to say that the Department has decided to pay salaries of day school teachers on a basis of ten teaching months in the school year.

In this connection, I enclose copy of circular letter of the 17th ultimo, which was forwarded to all Indian agents.

As your salary is $450.00 per annum, you were paid one-tenth of this amount, or, $45.00 for the month of September. At the end of each of the other three quarters in the school year, provided the school is open, you will receive $135.00.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Miss Dora Gedeon,

Dimock Creek,
August 5, 1925.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Canada.

Dear Sir:

I beg to say that I have not yet received bonus for June quarter. I have received a cheque of one hundred and eighty dollars ($80.00) mentioning salary only; therefore it is sufficient to let you know that I have not yet received bonus for June quarter. Kindly let me know the cause of delay in forwarding the said bonus, as I always did receive bonus for every quarter including salary.

Hoping this will not be too much of a disappointment; probably matters having changed concerning this affair; if so kindly give an explanation.

I am Yours Very Respectfully,

Dora Hildon (Signature)

Ottawa, August 14, 1925.

Madam:

In reply to your letter of the 5th instant, I have to say that payment of bonus to teachers of Indian day schools was discontinued on March 31st, last. Previous to that time, you received salary for the academic year at the rate of $450 plus bonus of $150, or a total of $600. Owing to the bonus being discontinued, your salary was increased from April first, last, from $450 to $600 for the ten teaching months. You were paid at the latter rate for the three months of the June quarter. You will note that there is no balance due you and that you are receiving payment at the same rate as when you were being allowed bonus.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Miss Dora Gideon,
Dimock Creek,

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY
Re: Maria Indian Day School

owing to increased attendance at this school it has been found necessary to appoint another teacher and Sister Mary of Mercy has been appointed at the rate of $50.00 a teaching month, effective September 1, 1943. Ottawa,

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Maria Indian Day School
No. 318

The staff at the above-mentioned school for the academic year 1944-45 will be as follows:

Sister Mary of Mercy
Sister Mary of the Sacred Heart replacing Sister Mary of St. Bernadette of Lourdes
Sister Mary of St. Brigitte

Sister Mary of the Sacred Heart should be paid salary at the rate of $60 a teaching month, plus bonus, effective September 1, 1944. I attach copy of letter of appointment and the other forms will be forwarded to you when received.

for Deputy Minister.
Ottawa, September 12, 1945.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY.

Ref: Maria Indian Day School, No. 318.

With reference to my memorandum of August 7, I am now advised that the list I sent you was not exactly correct.

The following is the correct adjustment of the staff:

Sister Mary of St. Adeline replaces Sister Mary of the Sacred Heart, as Principal.

Sister Mary of the Divine Heart replaces Sister Mary of Mercy.

The salaries are as follows:

Sr. Mary of St. Adeline - $65.00 per teaching month.
Sr. Mary of the Divine Heart - $50.00

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on conditions in the Maria Indian Agency.

The floor in the school house is in very bad condition and should be renewed this summer. The whole centre of the floor has sunk to such an extent that it is dangerous. As the school building is on a concrete foundation about the only way to remedy matters is to remove the present floor from the inside and insert new sleepers. This would require about twenty sleepers and some blocking. Material for a double floor would also have to be provided, one rough floor underneath and a birch floor on the top with paper between. The condition of this floor was brought to my attention last summer but I did not mention it partly on account of my knowledge of shortage of funds and partly because I thought that it might be let go for a time without becoming worse than it then was. Since then it has fallen more and will render the school unfit for occupation next winter.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. Sir:

Mr. Inspector Parker of this Department, who recently visited the Maria Indian Day School, states that the floor is in very bad condition and that the only way to remedy matters is to remove the present floor from the inside and insert new floor beams, which would require about 20 beams and some blocking. He also states that material for a double floor would be necessary - one rough floor underneath and a birch floor on the top with paper between. He reports that if this floor is not repaired the school will be unfit for occupation during next winter.

I have to request that you will forward a report as soon as possible, stating, in detail, the number of floor beams, rough flooring and birch flooring required, and the cost of the labour in having the work carried out. Sir:

I have your letter of the 14th ultimo, regarding the fuel required for use at the Maria Indian Day School for the coming winter and with reference to repairs required to the school building.

After the work has been completed, you should obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost of the materials and accounts in triplicate, for the labour. Sir,

I receive your kind greetings for Christmas and New Year, for which I sincerely thank you, and ask the Providence to grant you a good health and prosperity as Deputy General of Indian Affairs, this will be the greatest honor for me.

Though I had not much time to make you acquaintance on your short visit in the summer of 1935, I assure you I appreciate highly your courtesy and encouragement for the Indians and their hard times.

Permit me to inform you the situation is still improving much because of lack of employment or sales of industry work for the poor Indians, and I had to persuade them of the necessity of farming and gardening more than they used to do in good times. With this last spring help from the Department in furnishing seed and fertilizer, they made a little better than before, so they have potatoes and vegetables which is good to help them for winter but there is no fish in my pond. Though I am blamed for the great expenses for relief and clothing furnished in my agency, in fact, I have tried my best to cut down expenses without prejudice to the Indians. I would have done it long ago, but we are in special circumstances. The population is increasing and the Indian day school is too small, there being 48 pupils in a classroom for 26 pupils. I hope an appropriation would be voted at the next fiscal year to the effect of building an addition to the school in order to have two schoolrooms for the benefit of school children on Maria Reserve.

Believe me, Sir, your obedient servant,

Mr. Sutherland,

During my recent visit to the Maria Reserve I visited the Indian School. I found that there is a great deal of overcrowding, as many as three and four children sitting in one seat. The teacher, Miss Gedeon, informed me that there were many children absent partly due to there having been a dental clinic the day before. A great many teeth were extracted and some of the children must have felt far from well. The remainder of the absentees should have been looked after by the Truant Officer, Milton Gedeon.

On investigation I find that there appears to be a lack of co-operation between the Truant Officer and the teacher. The Truant Officer stated that he had not received a statement as to absentees for a long time while the teacher stated that she had furnished such a statement to the Indian Agent recently. When I interviewed the Agent he denied having received such a list from the teacher. To me it appears that the Truant Officer is not doing his duty partly due to lack of co-operation from the teacher and indifference on the part of the Agent.

A large supply of codliver oil has been furnished this school. The teacher informed me that only a few children were taking it. She stated that the other children's parents would not furnish them with a spoon to take to school to use for this purpose. I spoke to the Chief about the lack of co-operation between the Indians and the teacher and suggested that he use his influence to see that the children had the codliver oil which they appeared to need. Many of these children were suffering from head colds which would have benefited by the use of the oil supplied.
Miss Gedeon appears to have the children well under control. School equipment appears to be very old and dilapidated. The children did not appear to have any school work to do but were well behaved. I understand that Miss Gedeon is labouring under great difficulties; 53 children are too much for any one teacher to teach properly. When you add to this the overcrowding that we have at this place, you will see that she faces a very hopeless situation.

I would respectfully suggest that the Department consider the advisability of constructing a new school on this Reserve. Possibly a two roomed school is required to accommodate the 53 children now on the roll in addition to many young Indians between the ages of 13 and 15 who are not at present attending.

G. Armstrong,

At the present time, the school built forty years ago and repaired ten years ago is suitable for 25 pupils. There are 42 children registered and eight more should attend school. That is to say that the school should be made available for twice its capacity. It will be necessary to rebuild and provide two class-rooms, in order that two schoolmistresses may teach.

Under the circumstances, I believe the Department cannot refuse to spend the money, on account of the urgency.

I wish you would take the proposition into immediate consideration; and, should it be favourably looked upon, I wish you would advise me without delay.

If necessary, I could provide you with the plans draughted by the Quebec Department of Public Instruction for the type of school that will be needed, according to the number of pupils likely to attend.

Yours truly,

(Signed) P. Emile Coté.

Dear Mr. Cote:

I am directed to acknowledge receipt of your letter of November 27th and also copy of a communication received by you from Mr. A. Cyr, Indian Agent, Maria, Que., enclosed therewith.

I may state that the claims of the Indians of Maria for the erection of a new school at that point were carefully considered by the departmental officials when the estimates for the fiscal year 1938-39 were being prepared. In view of the urgent demands for school accommodation in other districts, it was not possible, however, to include an item for the erection of a school at Maria this year.

However, if the able-bodied Indians of Maria now in receipt of relief are prepared to secure logs or lumber and proceed with the construction of an additional schoolroom at that point, the Department will be prepared to provide windows, roofing, interior furnishings, etc. You will be interested to learn that a number of Indian bands throughout the Dominion have, in cooperation with the Department, established schools on this cooperative basis. It is our hope that the Indians of Maria will be prepared to undertake this task, in return for the relief allowances they are now receiving. Should they be prepared to do so, the officials will be glad to communicate with the Indian Agent and make arrangements to have this work started toward the beginning of the next fiscal year.

Re: Erection of new school on Maria Indian Reserve.

Memorandum:

The DEPUTY MINISTER,-

Reports on file indicate that there is a school on this reserve with accommodation for approximately 25 pupils. The Indian population of the reserve, according to the last census, is 209, and, of these, approximately 45 are of school age. It would appear, therefore, that additional school accommodation is required at this reserve and should be provided in the immediate future. No item, however, for the construction of a school at this point was included in the 1938-39 estimates. There are still a number of districts in which no provision whatever has been made for the education of the children, and it was felt by the officials of the Department that these districts should have first consideration.

A large proportion of the Indians of Maria are in receipt of relief allowances from the Department. The latest figures supplied from the Treasury Branch indicate that relief costs at Maria for the period April first to October 31, 1937, amounted to $3,588.31, and our expectation is that these figures will show a substantial increase during the winter months. I am suggesting, therefore, that the able-bodied Indians of this Band now in receipt of relief be asked to cut the logs necessary, or, if they so desire, secure the lumber and proceed with the construction of an additional room to the Maria school, in return for the relief allowances they are now receiving from the Department.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

With reference to Mr. Pratt's telephone message yesterday regarding the Maria Indian Day School I would refer you to the information contained in my memorandum of December 5, 1937.

There was considerable correspondence with the Indian Agent as the officers of this Branch were under the impression that the able-bodied Indians of the Maria Band who are now in receipt of relief would be willing to cut the logs and proceed with the construction of the building if the Department provided doors, windows, roofing material and interior furnishings. However, it was eventually found that these Indians were not willing to contribute their services free. The last letter received from the Indian Agent stated that the cost of labour would be approximately $2,000.00. He also suggested at that time that a two-roomed school be erected. This would involve the employment of a second teacher.

As no funds were provided for the amount that would apparently be required, nor were any funds provided for the salary of a second teacher at this school, it was decided not to take any further action in the matter at the present time.

The question of providing funds for a school in this Agency will be given further consideration when preparing our estimates for the fiscal year 1939-40.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter enclosing building data form with reference to the proposed erection of a day school on the Maria Reserve.

You state that it will cost $25.00 to purchase an extra half acre of land for a site for the school. To Secretary,

In answer to Mr. Smith's letter in regard to acquisition of a piece of land to erect a new school on Reserve, I must inform the Dept. that the present school yard (100 x 60) though not large, will be OK to build on. If the Indians are not reasonable enough to furnish the free of charge to have a proper school yard, I will advise them as to their hopes views on this matter and try to convince them to give in.

The decision to wire the school for lighting only is perfect. No pumping water could easily be done by hand, being a great quantity of water not being required to be sufficient for needs.

The approximate cost to dig a well would be about $300.00 if lined with cement and $75.00 if with cement pipe. The water level is 20 to 25 feet. The soil is quicksand to about 15 feet, and not rocky. The water is good at any time.

I reiterate my suggestion to have living quarters for the school and teachers in the new school, so boarding house costs can be saved from Reserve presently.

I remain your servant,

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle,

Re - Indian Day School, Maria Reserve, Quebec.

With reference to your memorandum of the 7th ultimo, I am forwarding herewith, for transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch, two copies of a sketch plan of a two room school with teacher's living quarters, which plan will provide the accommodation required for the above.

With regard to the provision of Septic Water System toilets, I may say that as the cost of installing such a service would be about $975.00 including the additional building space required and a sewage disposal bed, this service has been so located that it can be installed or omitted without affecting the building proper. I would be pleased to be advised whether the Indian Affairs Branch consider that this service should be installed as indicated on the plans at the above mentioned cost or, as suggested on the building data form, whether outside toilets for the children and an inside chemical toilet for the teacher will be satisfactory.

The cost of the proposed building, exclusive of the above mentioned septic toilets is estimated at about $9,125.00. I may say that this cost is in excess of the appropriation of $6,500.00 which apparently was included in the 1939-40 Estimates without regard for the size or requirements of this school. Unless a saving can be effected in connection with the appropriations for the other schools proposed to be erected under the same vote, additional funds will have to be provided to cover any over-expenditure incurred on this work.

In connection with the erection of this building, it is noted that although there are no skilled Indian tradesmen available on the Reserve, the Indian Affairs Branch have recommended construction by day labour, utilizing 15 Indians who could be employed under a reliable foreman. As skilled tradesmen would undoubtedly have to be employed on day labour work in addition to the general labour required and as provision is made under the general labour conditions governing contract work for the employment of Indian labour when such is available and competent, it is considered that the 15 Indians available for work on this project would receive equivalent employment insofar as general labour requirements.

Re - Electrical current for Maria Indian Day School, Quebec.

Attached herewith, for your information, is a copy of a letter received by our Engineer in charge of this project from the Chaleur Bay Power Limited of Trois Rivieres. You will note that this Company are ready to furnish electricity for the needs of the School, under the following conditions:-

(a) The Department to pay cost of materials required for installation to the amount of .............$196.86. The Company will assume the cost of labour and all maintenance costs, with the exception of the transformer. Maintenance costs in regard to the latter will remain a responsibility of the Department. (This apparently is to cover any damage to the transformer from windstorms or electrical storms, but such damage is rare and over a period of years would not exceed the original cost of the transformer - $125.00).

(b) The Department would pay electric light rates as follows:-
A charge of 15¢ per k.w.h. per month for light, heating and motive power, up to ½ h.p., including domestic appliances, with a minimum monthly payment of $1.50. Discount of 10% on payment within ten days.
In order that the necessary connection can be made from the Company's line to the School lighting system when the building is completed, it would be necessary for your Branch to write the Company applying for a connection under the above terms and conditions.

If it is your wish that the connection be made this fall, I would suggest that you send over a signed letter to us which we will transmit to our Engineer so that he can present it to the Company and make the necessary arrangements.

As your Branch is in the position of owner of this building, the application should come over your signature.

Director.

In answer to Mr. Phelan's letter, I beg to inform you that the greatest interference in each one's business comes from the Chief. Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Re: Electrical installation, Indian Day School, Maria Reserve.

In accordance with your request in regard to the above, all the information was obtained in regard to the costs of installation and rates charged by the Chaleur Bay Power Company and I am forwarding herewith a statement of the costs and several copies of application forms showing the rates charged. I may say that in comparing these rates with those formerly submitted to our Engineer, Mr. Sparks, the new rates are more favourable as the first quotation was a general rate of 15 cents for one year.

It would appear that the application for the power should be signed by your Branch and as we have no Engineer in this neighbourhood at the present time there is no doubt that your Agent can make all necessary arrangements for installation and opening of the service.

Director.
Ottawa,

Dear Sir:

With reference to the Maria Indian day school the Department understands that this school was wired for electricity and that electric light bulbs were supplied.

In order to make the necessary installations to supply electricity will involve an expenditure of $196.86 of which amount $125.00 is the cost of the transformer. At the present period of the fiscal year our funds are extremely limited and consequently it has been decided to defer installation of electricity. The electric light bulbs in the building should be removed and carefully stored in order to avoid breakage.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

I have for acknowledgment Mr. Pratt's memorandum of January 19, in which information is sought with respect to the enrolment at the Maria Indian Day School.

A two-room structure was built during the past summer on the Maria reserve, close to the main provincial highway that encircles the Gaspé peninsula. This school, at which provision has been made for the accommodation of two teachers, has also accommodation for the promotion of vocational instruction and for the serving of secondary meals. Inspector J. Albert Lesblanc, in his last report on this school dated November 16, 1939, states that the enrolment at that date was 66. The Inspector's reports also indicate that the two teachers in charge have both secured full academic and professional standing.

MEMORANDUM:

INSPECTION OF MARIA AGENCY - February 1940.

A visit to the new 2 class school was made in company with Agent Cyr, and Dr. McLean. The Department deserves credit for this fine building erected in 1939; class rooms are spacious, well lighted and ventilated; the living quarters are also interesting. The cellar is most conveniently used for the heating system installed at the centre, and so providing two large rooms, used as playrooms for boys and for girls on rainy days; the lighting is good, and the cement walls received a coat of aluminum paint which gives a very neat effect. I hope that in the near future we will start manual training for both boys and girls, as this cellar is a most ideal place for such undertaking. Attendance is very satisfactory and school children looked fairly healthy, due no doubt to the regular taking of their Cod Liver oil during the winter months.

School Water

The water supply is nil. The point driven in the sand to a depth of about 13 feet is not giving proper service, it being necessary to pump half an hour to get a pail of water.

Hand dug wells are giving continuous service at most of the Indian homes. I visited a well dug by Jos. Condo across the road from the school. This well is 23 feet deep with a diameter of 4 feet. RE: Maria Reserve

I beg to submit the following report of inspection of Maria Agency on June 18, 17 and 18.

Wood Shed

Requisition was previously made, in 1940 and delayed until 1941, for the construction of a suitable shed to protect fuel wood and prevent pilferage. A suitable shed would cost between two and three hundred dollars. So far the two large cement finished rooms in the basement have not been used for the purpose intended, i.e. handicraft for boys and domestic science for girls; such rooms might be partly used for piling furnace wood for the duration of the war, or until such time as funds permit the erection of a wood shed. However, as sisters are going to teach in future it is expected that the said rooms will be utilized for the purpose intended, in which case there remains no alternative but to pile wood, as before, and take a chance that Indians might refrain from picking a few sticks of wood whenever they run short.

Jude Thibault,
Inspector for Quebec.

Dear Sir,

Indian Reserve at Maria

Your Department will shortly receive the forms filled out by the Nuns who have been chosen by Mgr. Ross to teach at the Maria Indian Reserve. I am looking after this matter right away.

The agent, Mr. Napoléon Cyr, came to see me a few days ago regarding this. A toilet would have to be installed at the Indian School of Maria. Mr. Cyr is of the opinion that that would not cost very much. He dug a well and installed a pump and the whole work has cost only about $60. A cesspool would have to be dug and that would probably cost about $30; a small "reservoir" and a toilet would have to installed and the whole would cost about $100 including the cesspool.

I would be obliged if you would give the necessary orders to have that toilet room ready for the opening of the school. Mr. Cyr will do that work for us at a low price.

I would advise you also to give an increase of salary of $50 per year to Mr. Milton Gédéon, police officer of the Indian Reserve, so that he may look after the work of sending the Indian children to school every day. Mr. Gédéon came to see me also, at the same time as the agent, Mr. Napoléon Cyr. Both of them cooperate for the welfare of the Indians. Mr. Gédéon has acted as policeman in the reserve since many years and I have heard only praise about him. He is not paid to look after the work of sending the children to school, but he would do so for a small increase of salary and I am sure that if that work were given to him, he would do it honourably.

Hoping that all these matters will be settled before the opening of the school, I remain,

Yours truly,

J. Alphée Poirier, M.P.,
Bonaventure.

Dear Mr. Poirier:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of July 28 in which you discuss certain repairs that may be necessary at the Maria Indian Day School.

The officials of the Indian Affairs Branch inform me that it has never been the practice of the Government at any time to construct septic tanks or to provide water closets at Indian Day Schools. The desirability of installing water closets was carefully reviewed at the time the school was constructed and an estimate of the cost secured from the contractor. The lowest cost submitted for the work at that time was $970.00. The installation of water closets means in addition to the regular plumbing work the construction of a septic tank and the installation of a pressure pump operated by electrical energy or by the utilization of a small gas engine. You can readily appreciate that machinery of this kind requires the utmost care by an experienced caretaker and even when this care is exercised our experience at the larger residential schools has been that the septic tanks are constantly in need of repair.

In view of the Government's policy, therefore, and the fact that no provision was made for this work in the current year's estimates, it will not be possible to even consider undertaking this work. In the meantime, I have been informed by the officials that chemical toilets were installed at the time the school was constructed and that no complaint with respect to these has been received from the teachers by the Department at any time.

I have noted with interest your suggestion that the salary of Mr. Milton Gedeon be increased by $50.00 per annum. The records here indicate that Mr. Gedeon is paid $200 per annum for undertaking the duties . . . . . .

J. Alpheo Poirier, Esq., M.P.,
Boulevard, Quebec.

Cher monsieur Poirier,

J'ai bien reçu votre lettre du 28 juillet relative à certaines réparations qu'il sera peut-être nécessaire d'effectuer à l'établissement indien de Maria.

Les fonctionnaires de la division des Affaires Indiennes m'apprennent que le gouvernement n'a jamais eu pour pratique de construire des fosses septiques ou d'installer des W.C. aux établissements indiens. À l'époque où l'école a été construite, on a obtenu une estimation du coût de l'entrepreneur et la somme la plus basse était de 997,00. L'installation de W.C. existe, outre les travaux ordinaires de plomberie, la construction d'une fosse septique et l'installation d'une pompe à pression actionnée par un moteur électrique ou à essence. Vous n'avez aucune peine à comprendre, j'en suis sûr, que ces appareils doivent être soigneusement entretenus par un préposé qui s'y entend, et même lorsqu'il en est ainsi nous avons constaté par notre expérience aux internats importants que les fosses septiques exigent constamment des réparations.

En conséquence, vu l'attitude du gouvernement et le fait qu'aucune somme n'a été incluse dans les prévisions budgétaires de cette année pour ce travail, il nous est impossible de songer à l'entreprendre. Entre temps, les autorités de la division des Affaires Indiennes nous apprennent que des cabinets d'aisance chimiques ont été installés lorsque l'école fut construite et que le ministère n'a jamais reçu de plaintes à leur sujet de la part des institutrices.
J'ai pris note de votre suggestion à l'effet que le salaire de M. Milton Gédéon soit augmenté de $50.00 par année. D'après les dossiers, M. Gédéon reçoit $200.00 par année pour accomplir les fonctions de policier sur la Réserve. Je dois vous faire connaître sous ce rapport que nous ne avons actuellement aucun salaire aux officiers d'assiduité sur aucune Réserve au pays. Le ministère avait pour pratique de payer une petite somme aux officiers d'assiduité sur certaines Réserves, mais cette pratique a été abandonnée il y a environ un an. Une lettre-circulaire a alors été adressée aux comptables sur les Réserves, ainsi qu'aux institutrices produites aux écoles, les priant de se charger de la tâche qui incombeait antérieurement aux officiers d'assiduité jusqu'à la fin de la période critique que nous traversons actuellement. En raison du travail dont M. Gédéon est chargé à Maria, il serait difficile de trouver une justification pour augmenter son salaire dans le moment. Quoi qu'il en soit, je suis à votre disposition si vous désirez discuter cette question personnellement avec moi.

Bien à vous,

C.W. Jackson,
Sous-ministre suppléant.

Dear Mr. Jackson,

In connection with your letter of the 5th of August, allow me to state in answer to the second paragraph that it is not a complete bathroom that we are asking; it is only a request for a water closet that we made. I understand that your contractor had asked $970 for the complete installation of a bath room; but those contractors always reserve for themselves a large profit. You undoubtedly know that the agent, Mr. Cyr, got installed a good artesian well and a good pump for less than $75.

Consequently, what we would need now is a water tank, a W.C. and a cesspool. The whole could be had for about $130 according to the estimates of a plumber of Maria. That amount is far from that of $970 which you mention in your letter.

At any rate, Mr. Thibaut, your inspector, has discussed that matter fully with the agent, Mr. Cyr.

Would you kindly discuss this case with Mr. Thibaut as soon as he arrives at Ottawa in order that we may get an answer at your convenience.

Yours truly,

J. Alphée Poirier, M.P.,
Bonaventure.

Dear Sir:

A request has been submitted to the Department for the installation of an outdoor toilet in the teacher's residence at the Maria Indian Day School.

Ottawa, October 28, 1941.

Re: Inspection at Maria Agency

I beg to report on my last inspection on the 21 and 22 instant to the above agency.

X X X

SCHOOL

The attendance appears to have improved considerably this year.

The Sisters are preparing to start their course in domestic cooking; a new sewing machine arrived on the day of my visit, and it was most welcome.

A cesspool was under construction and toilet supplies are expected to arrive for installation within a few days.

The supply of fuel wood had already been delivered and piled on the grounds back of the school; quality of the wood is very good.

As a means of practical teaching of gardening, I recommend this fall, the ploughing of a corner of the school ground. This will not interfere with playing, as there is plenty of ground left for that purpose. From the Highway fence, twenty feet wide and a depth of about seventy feet along the side fence, will, in my opinion be a good start and the expense light. The purchase of a few garden tools is also recommended for next Spring.

Regarding domestic science, in the girls' room, I have recommended a cupboard be built with shelves to lock away all sewing materials, supplies, etc., as no such provision had been made when the building was erected; a table, about ten feet long by three feet wide is needed to cut cloth and to make over any clothing from army supplies which are being sent to the Agency. The Sisters are most anxious to teach the girls how to make over such clothing.

While I was there, the agent received permission to purchase chairs for the girls' room in the basement of the school.

May I hope that the Department will approve my recommendations above:

Ploughing of school garden, this Fall
Large table for girls' work room (estimated $10.)
Cupboard in basement (estimated $15.)
Garden tools for pupils' garden

Agent told me that a requisition was sent about two months ago for rubbers for school children, wool for knitting, etc., but to date, none of these supplies had been received.

Chief Abraham Martin and a few others, complained that they were not on the fuel wood list; they were told to clear up the old wood lot where, I was informed, there remains from 35 to 75 loads of wood which could be cut.

I was also informed that our order for 130 cords of 48" slabs, would start to be delivered to Indians whose names are on the list recommended by the Inspector and approved by the Department.

X X X

Jude Thibault,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Quebec Inspectorate
The Secretary,
Indian affairs branch,
Ottawa,
Ga.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo in which you report that the well at the Maria School is dry. It is regretted that this condition has arisen, although it is probably due to an excessive use of water. It is possible that within the next week or so the well may refill.

In the meantime I suppose it will be necessary for you to arrange to have water carried for the use of the school and teachers' residence. It is understood, of course, that you will only arrange for transporting the water absolutely necessary and the cost should be kept as low as possible. You should advise me immediately the approximate weekly cost of this service.

You might also let me have an estimate of the cost of deepening the present well in the spring.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

To the Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch

Kind Sir,

I think it quite advisable to acquaint you with the fact that water is wanting since a while at our Indian School here. To tell the truth, the well and pump have given very little satisfaction if any—that I know of—

The well is shovel-worked; and in spite of the devoted janitor's efforts every day at the pump, very little water mixed with ground and sand, therefore not drinkable, can be drawn—

Mr. Eye—our Agent—with another man worked at it without success—Money spent at a loss—

Our janitor is a very honest and devoted man; he worries over his unsuccessful attempt; and for his small salary ($10.00) a month—he has a good deal to do—if he would get discouraged.

17-1-5
it should be something to repent for.

I am appealing to you, kind sir, not only on account of the constant daily need of water there is in a school and at the teacher's residence, but especially for the sake of safety. As it is what could we do in case of fire? I feel very uneasy sometimes and mostly too... Electricity seems so near us would settle the matter... and others...

If you could only see how trying on the children's eyes seeing in the basement.

I trust you will kindly take the responsibility of the matter and better the situation as soon as possible.

With hearty anticipated thanks

I beg to remain

kind sir,

Respectfully Yours,

Sister Mary of Mercy
